title: Shuler v. Gregory Electric
description: Gregory Electric appeals from an order of the circuit court affirming the single commissioner and full commission's award of workers' compensation benefits to the surviviors of Linda Shuler, who died oon her return home from a doctor's office where she received treatment for a previous compesnable injury.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Kenneth Shuler, Husband, Jason Brandon Shuler, Minor Child and William Bryant Shuler, Minor Child, Beneficiaries of Linda Shuler, Deceased Employee,
Respondents,
v.
Gregory Electric, Employer and Comptrust AGC of South Carolina,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4039
Heard September 13, 2005 â€“ Filed November 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard C. Detwiler and Mikell H. Wyman, both of Columbia, for Appellants.
E. Courtney Gruber and R. WalterÂ  Hundley, both of Charleston, and
W. ScottÂ  Palmer, of Santee, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:  Gregory Electric appeals from an order of the circuit court affirming the single commissioner and full commissionâ€™s award of workersâ€™ compensation benefits to the survivors of Linda Shuler, who died on her return home from a doctorâ€™s office where she received treatment for a previous compensable injury.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
Shuler worked as an electricianâ€™s helper for Gregory Electric (Employer).Â  In August of 2001, Shuler injured her right hand while holding a ladder for a co-worker.Â  It is undisputed that Shulerâ€™s hand injury was work-related, and as a result of the injury, Shuler received treatment from an employer-authorized physical therapist and doctor in Columbia, South Carolina.Â  On November 15, 2001, Shuler left her home in Orangeburg, South Carolina at approximately 2:20 p.m. to receive physical therapy on her hand.Â  Although she did not have an appointment, she was able to see the physical therapist and doctor that afternoon, and left the doctorâ€™s office at 6:30 p.m.Â  
While exiting off of I-77 South onto I-26 East, Shuler drove into the guardrail on the right side of the exit ramp, overcorrected, and crashed headfirst into the guardrail on the left side of the exit ramp. Some time after the accident occurred, Albert Chatfield, III, was driving on the exit ramp and had to swerve into the right lane in order to avoid Shulerâ€™s car, the trunk of which was protruding into the road. Chatfield testified that he was â€œnot very sureâ€ of what time it was when he discovered Shulerâ€™s car, but guessed it was somewhere between 7:30 and 8:00 p.m.Â  Because Shulerâ€™s windows were very tinted and her doors were locked, Chatfield did not realize anyone was in the vehicle, but he called 911 because Shulerâ€™s vehicle posed a hazard for other motorists. 
Trooper Brian E. Kyzer from the South Carolina Highway Patrol responded to Chatfieldâ€™s call and arrived at the scene at 8:27 p.m.Â  Â When Trooper Kyzer arrived, he shined a flashlight into Shulerâ€™s car and saw that she was inside, slumped toward the passengerâ€™s seat.Â  He called an ambulance, but Shulerâ€™s injuries were fatal.Â  
The parties dispute Shulerâ€™s activities between the time she left the doctorâ€™s office and the time Shulerâ€™s car was found.Â  Trooper Kyzer testified that he found bags from a grocery store and a dollar store in Shulerâ€™s backseat and that Shulerâ€™s daughter had told him Shuler planned to go shopping after her visit to the doctor.[1]Â  Based on his investigation, Trooper Kyzer surmised that the accident occurred at 8:15 p.m., give or take a few minutes. 
The single commissioner awarded benefits to Shulerâ€™s husband and her dependent children, finding the accident arose out of and in the course of her employment.Â  In making this finding, the commissioner noted that Shuler was bound by the terms of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act at the time of the accident and that she could have lost her right to weekly benefits if she failed to receive the authorized medical treatment as directed. The single commissioner further found that Shulerâ€™s car could have been on the side of the road for some time before it was discovered, that Trooper Kyzerâ€™s estimated time of the accident was not based on any personal knowledge, and that the exact time of Shulerâ€™s accident could never be definitively established.Â  The commissioner took judicial notice ofÂ  â€œthe fact that 6:30 â€“ 7:30 p.m. is considered by many to be the â€˜supper hour,â€™â€ and found that even if Shuler stopped at a grocery store after her visit to the doctorâ€™s office, â€œsuch a stop would be insubstantial and would be covered under the allowed â€˜personal comfortâ€™ deviation.â€Â  Finally, the commissioner found that Shuler was being paid mileage by Employer for this trip to her physical therapist and doctor.Â  
Employer appealed to the full commission, which adopted the single commissionerâ€™s order verbatim.Â  Employer then appealed to the circuit court, which also affirmed the award of benefits.Â  The circuit court found that because Employer reimbursed Shuler for mileage while traveling to the doctorâ€™s office, her accident fell within an exception to the general rule that an employee is not covered by workersâ€™ compensation while traveling to and from work.Â  The circuit court also found Shuler was performing a special errand by visiting her physical therapist and doctor, which qualified her trip for another recognized exception to the going and coming rule.Â  While the circuit court disagreed that Shulerâ€™s trip to the store fell within the personal comfort doctrine, it found she was entitled to benefits because at the time of the accident she had resumed her business route.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Generally, it is a question of fact whether an injury arose out of and was in the scope of employment.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 159, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999) (citation omitted).Â  Because causation is a question of fact, the full commissionâ€™s decision on the issue must be affirmed if it is supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  Id. at 160, 519 S.E.2d at 105.Â  However, we may reverse or modify the commissionâ€™s decision if it is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 288-89, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610-11 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Substantial evidence is that which, in viewing the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the full commission reached.Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 183, 528 S.E.2d 435, 440 (Ct. App. 2000) (citation omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Arising Out of and in the Scope of EmploymentÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Employer first argues Shulerâ€™s accident, which occurred on her way home from an unscheduled, unannounced doctorâ€™s appointment, neither arose out of nor was in the scope of her employment as an electricianâ€™s helper.Â  In support of its argument, Employer cites to Douglas v. Spartan Mills, Startex Div., 245 S.C. 265, 140 S.E.2d 173 (1965). 
In Douglas, the claimant sustained a compensable injury while working as a doffer at a mill and received temporary disability benefits.Â  He returned to work, but filed a claim seeking additional benefits for permanent partial disability and disfigurement.Â  Id. at 266-267, 140 S.E.2d at 173-174.Â  A hearing was set for the morning of September 20, 1965, but claimant misread the notice and reported for work that morning.Â  Id. at 267, 140 S.E.2d at 174.Â  Claimantâ€™s attorney called the mill, and claimantâ€™s supervisor notified him of his hearing and allowed him to leave.Â  Claimant went home, changed clothes, and was on his way to the hearing when his steering gear failed, and he ran into a bridge abutment.Â  Claimant sought workersâ€™ compensation benefits for the injuries he sustained in the accident, and the single commissioner, full commission, and circuit court all agreed that he was entitled to benefits.Â  Id.Â  However, the supreme court reversed, finding the accident did not arise in the course of employment.Â  Specifically, the court stated: â€œThe causative danger here was the defective steering apparatus on the claimantâ€™s automobile, which we think was clearly independent of the relation of master and servant and not incidental to the character of the business or the employment.â€Â  Id. at 269, 140 S.E.2d at 175.Â  The court further noted that â€œ[t]he only connection which the employer had with the particular accident was that the employer cooperated with and accommodated the claimant and his attorney in notifying the claimant and letting him off from work for the purpose of attending a hearing which claimant had sought for his own benefit.â€Â  Id. at 270, 140 S.E.2d at 175.
Like the claimant in Douglas, Employer points out that Shuler was operating her personal vehicle at the time of the accident and was exposed only to the dangers of driving an automobile on a public road.Â  However, unlike the claimant in Douglas, Shuler was traveling from a medical visit, albeit unplanned, that was necessitated by her previous compensable injury.Â  Because she was bound by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, she was required to visit this particular doctorâ€™s office in Columbia or she risked losing her benefits.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 (1985) (â€œThe refusal of an employee to accept any medical, hospital, surgical or other treatment when provided by the employer or ordered by the Commission shall bar such employee from further compensation until such refusal ceases . . . unless in the opinion of the Commission the circumstances justified the refusal . . . .â€).
Not only is Douglas distinguishable from the case at hand, but so too are all reported South Carolina cases.Â  Thus, we consider jurisprudence from other jurisdictions to determine the compensability of additional injuries a claimant sustains while journeying to or from a doctorâ€™s office for a previous work-related injury.Â  Although there is authority to the contrary,[2] most states that have addressed this issue find an injury suffered during such a journey is compensable.Â  1 Arthur Larson & Lex K. Larson, Workersâ€™ Compensation Law, Â§ 10.07 (Compensable Consequences) (2004).Â  
In Taylor v. Centex Constr. Co., 379 P.2d 217 (Kan. 1963), the Kansas Supreme Court held that an injury sustained by an employee while traveling to medical treatment for a prior compensable injury arose out of and in the course of employment.Â  In Taylor, claimant suffered an eye injury while working for Centex Construction as a cement mason foreman.Â  Centex allowed him to visit a doctor for his injury, which claimant did.Â  On his way back from the doctor, claimant had his truck greased at his sonâ€™s service station and ate lunch.Â  He then stopped by a convenience store, purchased a drink, and when he was within two miles of his job site, he collided with a road sweeper, sustaining serious injuries to his knee.Â  Id. at 218.Â  In finding that claimantâ€™s knee injuries were compensable, the Kansas Supreme Court noted that pursuant to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, an employer is under a duty to furnish medical care.Â  Likewise, an employee is under a duty to submit to reasonable medical treatment.Â  These statutory duties become part of the employment contract by implication, and therefore, an accidental injury sustained while en route to or from treatment for a compensable injury is work related because it is made pursuant to contractual obligations.Â  Id. at 221.Â  
We agree with the reasoning set forth in Taylor.Â  Under the law of workersâ€™ compensation, employers must furnish, and employees must submit to, medical treatment for work-related injuries.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 42-15-60 and 42-15-80 (Supp. 2004).Â  Thus, when an employer authorizes an employee to seek medical attention for a prior injury and the employee sustains additional injuries while fulfilling her obligation to submit to medical treatment, such additional injuries are sufficiently causally related to employment to be compensable.Â  See also Font v. New York City Bd. of Educ, 566 N.Y.S.2d 754, 755 (1991) (holding that injuries claimant suffered while traveling to a doctorâ€™s office for treatment of another compensable injury were work-related and compensable); Moreau v. Zayre Corp., 408 A.2d 1289, 1293-94 (Me. 1979) (awarding benefits to claimant who was injured in an automobile accident while driving home after receiving medical treatment for a previously compensable hand injury because the employee had a correlative duty to accept medical treatment for the initial compensable injury and therefore was fulfilling an implied duty of the employment contract when she got into the accident); Bero v. Workmenâ€™s Comp. Appeal Bd., 645 A.2d 342, 345 (Pa. Commw. Ct. 1994) (finding that â€œbut-forâ€ driving to his physical therapist for treatment of his work-related injury, claimant would not have been in the car accident that caused additional injuries, and therefore the additional injuries were compensable).[3]
Here, Shulerâ€™s fatal accident occurred while she was fulfilling her duty to submit to treatment for a previous compensable injury.Â  Thus, her subsequent injuries arose out of and were in the scope of her employment.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  â€œGoing and Comingâ€ Rule
Employer next argues the circuit court erred by finding Shulerâ€™s accident fell within an exception to the â€œgoing and comingâ€ rule.Â  Under this rule, an employee who is going to or coming from work is generally not considered to be engaged in performing any service growing out of or incidental to employment, and therefore, an injury sustained by accident at such a time does not arise out of and in the course of employment.Â  McDaniel v. Bus Terminal Rest. Mgmt. Corp., 271 S.C. 299, 247 S.E.2d 321 (1978)).Â  As discussed above, we believe Shuler was, at the time of her accident, performing a service that was incidental to her employment in that she was fulfilling her obligation under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act to submit to treatment.Â  Thus, her injuries were sufficiently related to her employment so as to place the accident outside the parameters of the â€œgoing and comingâ€ rule.
III.Â Â Â  Intervening Personal Deviations
Finally, Employer argues the award of death benefits should be reversed because of the intervening personal deviations between the time Shuler left the doctorâ€™s office and the time of her accident.Â  We disagree.
The full commission found that even if Shuler stopped by the grocery store after her treatment in order to purchase supper for her family, such a deviation was â€œinsubstantial and would be covered under the allowed â€˜personal comfortâ€™ [doctrine].â€Â  The circuit court found this ruling was erroneous because the application of the personal comfort doctrine â€œhas consistently been limited to imperative acts such as eating, drinking, smoking, seeking relief from discomfort, preparing to begin or quit work, and resting or sleeping.â€Â  Osteen v. Greenville County Schoool District, 333 S.C. 43, 47-48, 508 S.E.2d 21, 23 (1998).Â  However, the circuit court found Shulerâ€™s injuries were compensable even in light of her deviation to the store because at the time of her accident, she had returned to the route of the business trip.Â Â  
Upon reviewing the record, we note the commission never actually found Shuler had deviated from her route to go shopping.Â  Rather, the commission first found that the time of the accident could never be clearly established and that Shuler may have stopped to eat dinner between 6:30 p.m. and 7:30 p.m.Â  Only after making those findings did the commission go on to find that even if Shuler did stop by the grocery store to buy dinner for her family, such a trip would be encompassed by the personal comfort doctrine. 
There is substantial evidence in the record supporting the commissionâ€™s findings.Â  See Gibson v. Spartanburg School Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 516, 526 S.E.2d 725, 728 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œIn an appeal from the Commission, this Court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.â€).Â  No one witnessed Shulerâ€™s accident, and as the Good Samaritan who called in the accident testified, numerous cars drove around Shulerâ€™s wrecked vehicle without calling authorities.Â  Thus, her car may have been on the road for a substantial period of time before Trooper Kyzer investigated the scene.Â  Furthermore, although Trooper Kyzer testified that Shulerâ€™s daughter told him her mother planned to stop at the grocery store after her doctorâ€™s visit, when Shulerâ€™s daughter testified, she denied ever saying such a thing.Â  There was no evidence presented regarding how long the shopping bags had been in Shulerâ€™s backseat or whether the bags contained perishable items.Â  Thus, there is substantial evidence to support a finding that Shuler did not deviate from her business trip. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find Shulerâ€™s death resulted from an accident arising from and in the course of her employment.Â  The going and coming rule does not preclude her from receiving benefits, and there is substantial evidence Shuler did not deviate from her route home.Â  Accordingly, the award of benefits is 
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, J., concurs, and KITTREDGE, J., dissents in a separate opinion.
KITTREDGE, J.:Â  I respectfully dissent, for I believe that Linda Shulerâ€™s November 18, 2001, motor vehicle accidentâ€”following the unscheduled doctorâ€™s appointmentâ€”did not arise out of and in the course of her employment with Gregory Electric.Â  I would reverse.
Since the essential facts are undisputed, the question before us is one of law.Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 517, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000).
Â The disposition of this appeal requires a proper understanding and application of the statutory requirement that an injury, to be compensable, must â€œaris[e] out of and in the course of the employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2004).Â  I find our supreme courtâ€™s decision in Douglas v. Spartan Mills, Startex Division, 245 S.C. 265, 140 S.E.2d 173 (1965), persuasive, both factually and legally.
There, David Douglas filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim against his employer, Spartan Mills.Â  The Industrial Commission, predecessor to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, scheduled a hearing at the Spartanburg Courthouse on the morning of September 20, 1961.Â  Douglas misread the hearing notice and reported for work that morning at the Startex plant.Â  A supervisor notified Douglas of the hearing about one hour before the hearing was to begin.Â  Douglas left work, drove home to change clothes and then headed to the courthouse, about a three-mile drive.Â  Douglas was injured in a motor vehicle accident en route to the courthouse.Â  The accident was caused by a defective steering mechanism.Â  Douglas filed a claim for compensation as a result of the September 20 accident.Â  Id. at 267, 140 S.E.2d at 174.Â  
The Commission found Douglas had sustained a compensable injury by accident, arising out of and in the course of employment.Â  Id. at 266, 140 S.E.2d at 173.Â  The circuit court affirmed.Â  Our supreme court reversed and held, as a matter of law, that Douglasâ€™s injury did not arise out of and in the course of his employment:

While the Workmenâ€™s Compensation Act has to be construed liberally in favor of coverage, and doubtful cases should be resolved in favor of the injured employee, we think the accident here clearly did not arise out of and in the course of the employment of the claimant, within the intent of the legislature in enacting the Workmenâ€™s Compensation Act. 

Id. at 270, 140 S.E.2d at 175-176
The courtâ€™s discussion of the separate elementsâ€”â€œarising out ofâ€ and â€œin course of employmentâ€â€”is helpful in determining the compensability of Shulerâ€™s accident following her visit to the doctor on November 18, 2001.Â  Both elements must be present for an accident to be compensable, and they must be concurrent and simultaneous.Â  Id. at 268, 140 S.E.2d at 174.Â  â€œâ€˜[T]he words â€˜arising out ofâ€™ refer to the origin of the cause of the accident, while the words â€˜in the course of employment,â€™ have reference to the time, place and circumstances under which the accident occurs.â€™â€Â  Id. at 268-69, 140 S.E.2d at 175 (quoting Eargle v. S.C. Elec. & Gas Co., 205 S.C. 423, 32 S.E.2d 240 (1944).Â  
An injury â€œarises out ofâ€ the employment when a causal connection exists between the conditions under which the work is required to be performed and the resulting injury.Â  Douglas, 245 S.C. at 269, 140 S.E.2d at 175 (quoting In re Employersâ€™ Liab. Assurance Corp., 102 N.E. 697 (Mass. 1913)).Â  The court described this causal link as follows: 

Under this test, if the injury can be seen to have followed as a natural incident of the work and to have been contemplated by a reasonable person familiar with the whole situation as a result of the exposure occasioned by the nature of the employment, then it arises â€˜out ofâ€™ the employment. But it excludes an injury which cannot fairly be traced to the employment as a contributing proximate cause and which comes from a hazard to which the workmen would have been equally exposed apart from the employment. The causative danger must be peculiar to the work and not common to the neighborhood. It must be incidental to the character of the business and not independent of the relation of master and servant. It need not have been foreseen or expected, but after the event it must appear to have had its origin in a risk connected with the employment, and to have flowed from that source as a rational consequence.Â  


    Â Id.
With respect to the requirement that the accident arise â€œin the course of employment,â€ the court explained: 

  An injury arises in the course of employment within the meaning of the Workmenâ€™s Compensation Act when it occurs within the period of employment at a place where the employee reasonably may be in the performance of his duties, and while he is fulfilling those duties, or engaged in doing something incidental
      thereto.

  Douglas, 245 S.C. at 269, 140 S.E.2d at 175 (quoting Fowler v. Abbott Motor Co., 236 S.C. 226, 113 S.E.2d 737 (1960)).
Applying these rules of reason to Douglasâ€™s accident while en route from work to his workersâ€™ compensation hearing, the supreme court found the accident â€œwas clearly not a compensable one.Â  The causative danger here was the defective steering apparatus on the claimantâ€™s automobile, which we think was clearly independent of the relation of master and servant and not incidental to the character of the business or the employment.â€Â  Douglas, 245 S.C. at 270, 140 S.E.2d at 175.Â  
I think it is at least equally clear that Shulerâ€™s November 18 accident, following her doctorâ€™s visit for a prior work-related injury, lacked the requisite causal connection to her employment and was in no manner incidental to the character of her employment with Gregory Electric.Â  Under Douglas, the accident must result from some exposure peculiar to the employment, and not a hazard to which all workers are equally exposed.Â  Id. at 269, 140 S.E.2d at 175.Â  Additionally, the injury arises in the course of employment only when it occurs at a place where the employee reasonably may be in the performance of her duties or â€œsomething incidental thereto.â€Â  Id.Â  The accident occurred while Shuler was driving her own vehicle on a public road.Â  Her duties as an employee did not require anything of her at the time and place of the accident.Â  See id. at 270, 140 S.E.2d at 175.Â  Instead, the doctorâ€™s visit was required only for compensation under the statute.Â  
The majority assigns significance to an injured employeeâ€™s statutory obligation to pursue required medical treatment as a condition of continued entitlement to workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  I do not view this â€œduty to submit to treatmentâ€ as a sufficient nexus to employment to satisfy the â€œarising out ofâ€ and â€œin course of employmentâ€ elements.Â  
An employee does not need a statute to know there is a duty to report to work, for an employee must show up at work to keep her job.Â  Yet we readily acknowledge that under normal circumstances the â€œgoing and comingâ€ rule would preclude recovery to an employee injured while traveling to or from work.Â  See McDaniel v. Bus Terminal Rest. Mgmt. Corp., 271 S.C. 299, 302, 247 S.E.2d 321, 322 (1978) (holding that pursuant to the â€œgoing and comingâ€ rule, injuries sustained while an employee is going to or coming from work generally are not compensable because the injuries do not arise out of and in the course of employment.)Â  The rationale for the rule is straightforwardâ€”traveling risks are those shared by public.Â  
Were Shuler going to or from her job at Gregory Electric, I do not believe we would entertain the notion that an accident was work-related.Â  Application of the â€œgoing and comingâ€ rule would foreclose such a claim.Â  Since the court today professes continued adherence to the â€œgoing and comingâ€ rule, it seems to me that todayâ€™s policy decisionâ€”the finding of a compensable, work related injuryâ€”would serve to favor those going to or from a doctorâ€™s visit over those employees actually working who must travel to and from work.Â  I do not understand the policy reasons for elevating the rights of those going to and from the doctorâ€™s office over workers traveling to and from work.
I believe that the Douglas holding and analysis controls here, and I would not resort to canvassing the law in other states, where the decisions predictably go both ways.Â  I would follow the lead of our supreme court in Douglas: 

If it is the intent of the legislature to include within the terms of the Workmenâ€™s Compensation Act employees injured while engaged in activities not in the course of their employment, though arising indirectly by reason of their employment, then the Act will have to be accordingly amended.Â  

Douglas, 245 S.C. at 270-271, 140 S.E.2d at 176 (quoting Fountain v. Hartsville Oil Mill, 207 S.C. 119, 32 S.E.2d 11 (1945)).Â  See also Wigfall v. Tideland Utils., Inc., 354 S.C. 100, 110, 580 S.E.2d 100, 105 (2003) (holding that because workersâ€™ compensation statutes provide an exclusive compensatory system in derogation of common law rights, they must be strictly construed, leaving ambiguities to be resolved by the legislature).Â  
The General Assembly has yet to accept this now 40-year-old invitation to amend the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act to provide for coverage in such circumstances.Â  Nor has our supreme court sought to retreat from its holding in Douglas.Â  Based on my view of prevailing South Carolina law, I would reverse the award of workerâ€™s compensation benefits to the estate of Linda Shuler.

[1] Shulerâ€™s daughter testified that she never told Trooper Kyzer her mother planned to go shopping before returning to Orangeburg. 
[2] See, e.g., Wyoming ex rel. Wyo. Workersâ€™ Safety & Comp. Div. v. Bruhn, 951 P.2d 373, 377-78 (Wyo. 1997) (denying benefits to claimant who died while returning from treatment for a compensable injury because â€œ[t]he accident was not a hazard of her employment that she would not have been subjected to apart from her job nor did it result from a risk reasonably incident to the character of the businessâ€); Lee v. Industrial Commâ€™n, 656 N.E.2d 1084, 1088 (Ill. 1995) (refusing to award benefits for injuries claimant sustained while crossing the street after receiving treatment from an employer-approved medical clinic because the claimant was under no duty or obligation to receive treatment at the time he did); Gayler v. North Am. Van Lines, 566 N.E.2d 84 (Ind. Ct. App. 4 Dist. 1991) (denying compensation for injuries claimant suffered while on her way to pick up a piece of medical equipment that was part of her prescribed treatment for a previous work-related accident; the court found that even though the employer agreed to pay for the medical equipment and had authorized treatment, the intervening negligence of a third party broke the causal link between the claimant and her employment). 
[3] We acknowledge that some states, such as Florida, have a statute addressing this very issue.Â  See Fla. Stat. Â§ 440.092(5) (â€œInjuries caused by a subsequent intervening accident arising from an outside agency which are the direct and natural consequence of the original injury are not compensable unless suffered while traveling to or from a health care provider for the purpose of receiving remedial treatment for the compensable injury.â€).Â  Notably, Floridaâ€™s statute was enacted in 1990, and prior to its enactment, Florida courts had already awarded benefits to claimants who suffered injuries en route to medical treatment for a previous compensable injury.Â  See, e.g., All American Wheel World, Inc. v. Gustafson, 499 So.2d. 876, 877 (Fla. App. Dist. 1 1986) (finding that the injury claimant sustained in an automobile accident while on his way to receive treatment from a chiropractor for a previous compensable injury was also compensable); see also IMC Phosphates Co. v. Prater, 895 So.2d 1263, 1269 (Fla. App. Dist. 1 2005) (discussing section 440.092(5) and the date of its enactment). Likewise, those jurisdictions cited above which favor compensation have made their rulings despite having no statute directly on point.Â

title: Commander Health Care Facilities v. SCDHEC
description: In this declaratory judgment action, Commander Health Care Facilities, Inc. appeals (1) the circuit court's finding that it lacked standing to maintain a declaratory judgment action against the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control and Heritage Home of Florence, and (2) the circuit court's grant of summary judgment in favor of DHEC and Heritage Home.  We reverse and remand.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Commander Health Care Facilities, Inc., Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control and Heritage Home of Florence, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4040
Heard September 12, 2005 â€“ Filed November 7, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Wm. Howell Morrison and Phyllis W. Ewing, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
Cheryl Harris Bullard and Matthew Summers Penn, both of Columbia and Karl A. Folkens and Philip B. Atkinson, both of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In this declaratory judgment action, Commander Health Care Facilities, Inc. appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control and Heritage Home of Florence.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Commander Health Care Facilities and Heritage Home of Florence both operate nursing home facilities in Florence County.Â  In 1997, Heritage Home applied for and was granted a certificate of need by the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) for the replacement of 44 Medicaid beds with 44 residential care beds.Â  In May 1998, Heritage Home applied for another certificate of need for the addition of 60 new nursing home beds to be dedicated to serving Medicaid patients. 
In June 1998, the South Carolina legislature passed the 1998 Appropriation Bill, including Proviso 9.35 which appropriated funds for Medicaid patient days for the 1998-1999 fiscal year.Â  This bill, which became effective on July 1, 1998, authorized a substantial number of additional Medicaid patient days and set forth provisions for granting permits for the additional Medicaid days â€œnotwithstanding any other provision of law.â€Â  At the time this bill passed, Heritage Home had already requested approval of additional Medicaid beds through the May certificate of need. 
In September 1998, DHEC Commissioner Douglas E. Bryant wrote Senator Hugh Leatherman of Florence, requesting an interpretation of Proviso 9.35.Â  As a result of that letter, Bryant and Senator Leatherman researched the legislative intent of the proviso and determined the proviso applied to currently licensed beds plus those nursing home beds issued under a 1998 certificate of need.Â  Senator Leatherman also opined in the letter that Proviso 9.35 would allow for the expansion of Medicaid beds without requiring a certificate of need.Â  Commissioner Bryant stated the â€œlegislative intent was to maximize the number of beds available.â€Â  Moreover, Albert Whiteside, Director of the Division of Planning and Certification of Need with DHEC, testified because the number of new Medicaid beds approved by the legislature in 1998 exceeded the number of requests for additional Medicaid beds from nursing homes, no application for new Medicaid beds was denied in 1998. 
On October 5, 1998, DHEC authorized Heritage Home to license 44 additional Medicaid beds under Proviso 9.35 and withdrew Heritage Homeâ€™s pending May 1998 certificate of need.Â  DHEC never issued a certificate of need for the new Medicaid beds; the only approval was pursuant to Proviso 9.35. Â Commander never applied for any of the additional Medicaid beds under Proviso 9.35.Â  Nor did DHEC deny Commander approval for additional beds under the proviso. Â Â 
In June 2000, Commander filed a declaratory judgment action seeking to overturn DHECâ€™s approval of additional new Medicaid beds for Heritage Home.Â  Commander also sought a declaration that DHECâ€™s grant of permission to Heritage Home to build new Medicaid beds under Proviso 9.35 without obtaining a formal certificate of need was in violation of the provisions of the South Carolina Code prohibiting special legislation.Â  In addition, Commander sought a permanent injunction prohibiting DHEC from authorizing the construction of new Medicaid beds under Proviso 9.35 without requiring facilities to obtain a formal certificate of need. Â Â Commander and Heritage, together with DHEC, filed cross-motions for summary judgment.Â  Heritage Home and DHEC argued Commander lacked the standing necessary to maintain the declaratory judgment action.Â  The circuit court agreed, and granted the motion.Â Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Commander argues the circuit court erred in (1) finding Commander lacked standing, and (2) granting summary judgment in favor of Heritage Home and DHEC.Â  We agree.
I.                  Standing
Commander contends the circuit court erred in finding that it suffered no injury in fact, and therefore, lacked standing to maintain the declaratory judgment action.Â  We agree.
As a general rule, to have standing, a litigant must have a personal stake in the subject matter of the litigation.[1]Â  Glaze v. Grooms, 324 S.C. 249, 478 S.E.2d 841 (1996).Â  Moreover, a private individual may not invoke the judicial power to determine the validity of an executive or legislative act unless the private individual can show that, as a result of that action, a direct injury has been sustained, or that there is immediate danger a direct injury will be sustained.Â  Joytime Distribs. & Amusement Co., Inc. v. State, 338 S.C. 634, 639, 528 S.E.2d 647, 649-50 (1999). Â Â The injury must be of a personal nature to the party bringing the action, not merely of a general nature that is common to all members of the public. Quality Towing, Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 340 S.C. 29, 34, 530 S.E.2d 369, 371 (2000).
However, â€œthe rule of standing is not an inflexible one.â€Â  Thompson v. South Carolina Commâ€™n on Alcohol & Drug Abuse, 267 S.C. 463, 467, 229 S.E.2d 718, 719 (1976).Â  Standing may be conferred upon a party â€œwhen an issue is of such public importance as to require its resolution for future guidance.â€Â  Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 531, 511 S.E.2d 69, 75 (1999).Â  Recently, South Carolina courts have held standing may be conferred upon a party when an issue is of such public importance as to require its resolution for future guidance.Â  See Sloan v. Wilkins, 362 S.C. 430, 608 S.E.2d 579 (2005); see also Sloan v. Sanford, 357 S.C. 431, 593 S.E.2d 470 (2004) (finding standing existed to challenge governorâ€™s commission as an officer in the Air Force reserve); Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 548, 590 S.E.2d 338, 347 (Ct. App. 2003) (finding standing to bring declaratory judgment action alleging county failed to comply with ordinances governing procurement of construction services on design-build public works projects).
In Sloan v. Wilkins, 362 S.C. 430, 608 S.E.2d 579 (2005), a taxpayer sought to challenge a legislative enactment as violative of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  Sloan challenged the legislative enactment as violative of the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s â€œone subject provisionâ€ as found in Art. 3, section 17.Â  Wilkins argued Sloan lacked the standing necessary to maintain an action challenging the legislative enactment.Â  The supreme court, in its original jurisdiction, found Sloan had the standing to challenge the legislative enactment â€œin light of the great public importance of this matter.â€Â  Wilkins, 362 S.C. at 437, 608 S.E.2d at 583.Â  The supreme court held that â€œstanding may be conferred upon a party when an issue is of such public importance as to require its resolution for future guidance.â€Â  Id.
Similar to the action taken in Wilkins, Commander seeks to challenge a legislative enactment, Proviso 9.35 of the 1998 Appropriations Bill, as violating the established certificate of need program as required by the State Certificate of Need and Health Facility Licensure Act contained in section 44-7-110, et seq. of the South Carolina Code (2002).Â  We deem the legislatureâ€™s funding and regulation of the stateâ€™s nursing home facilities, especially the regulation of Medicaid and Medicaid spending, an issue of great public importance.Â  Moreover, the legislature has the opportunity in each yearâ€™s Appropriations Bill to regulate the nursing home industry and corresponding Medicaid requirements.Â  Therefore, in light of the great public importance and need for future guidance for the legislature in this area, we find Commander has standing to maintain this action.
II.               Summary Judgment
Commander argues the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Heritage and DHEC.Â  Specifically, Commander contends a material issue of fact exists as to whether the term â€œMedicaid patient daysâ€ as used in Proviso 9.35 is synonymous with the use of â€œMedicaid patient bedsâ€ as used in the certificate of need program.Â  We agree.
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court must apply the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  South Carolina Elec. & Gas Co. v. Town of Awendaw, 359 S.C. 29, 34, 596 S.E.2d 482, 485 (2004).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when there are no genuine disputes of material facts and a party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56, SCRCP; Etheridge v. Richland School Dist. One, 341 S.C. 307, 311, 534 S.E.2d 275, 277 (2000).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  â€œOn appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.â€Â  Id.
Here, Heritage applied for the additional Medicaid beds under Proviso 9.35, and its original certificate of need for the beds was withdrawn.Â  Based on Heritageâ€™s application for the beds under the Proviso, DHEC issued 44 additional Medicaid beds.Â  Proviso 9.35 addresses provisions for granting permits for the â€œadditional Medicaid daysâ€ while the Certificate of Need program focuses on â€œadditional Medicaid beds.â€Â  DHEC maintains the terms are used interchangeably, and that one Medicaid bed equals 365 Medicaid patient days, therefore enabling DHEC to grant the 44 beds under the Proviso.Â  However, DHEC cannot point to any case, statute, regulation, or provision that has established this â€œformulaâ€ to be the universally accepted definition in the nursing home community.Â  Therefore, we find a material issue of fact exists as to whether the term â€œMedicaid patient daysâ€ as used in Proviso 9.35 is synonymous with the use of â€œMedicaid patient bedsâ€ as used in the certificate of need program.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Heritage Home and DHEC.
CONCLUSION
Because the circuit court erred in finding Commander lacked standing, and in granting summary judgment in favor of Heritage and DHEC, the decision of the circuit court is hereby
 REVERSED and REMANDED.
 BEATTY and SHORT, J.J. concur.

[1] â€œA party seeking to establish standing must prove the â€˜irreducible constitutional minimum of standing,â€™ which consists of three elements: (1) the plaintiff must have suffered an injury in fact; (2) the injury and the conduct complained of must be causally connected; and (3) it must be likely, rather than merely speculative, that the injury will be redressed by a favorable decision.â€Â  Sea Pines Assâ€™n for the Prot. of Wildlife v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res. & Cmty. Servs. Assocs., Inc., 345 S.C. 594, 601, 550 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2001) (quoting Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 55 (1992)).

title: Maurice Bessinger and Piggy Park Enterprises v. BI-LO
description: The primary issue in this appeal is whether the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act allows a manufacturer to sue a retailer for discontinuing the plaintiff's product because the plaintiff has publicly expressed controversial viewpoints.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Maurice Bessinger and Piggy Park Enterprises, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
BI-LO, Inc, Respondent.
_______________
Maurice Bessinger and Piggy Park Enterprises, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
The Kroger Co. and Mark Gray, Respondents.
_______________
Maurice Bessinger and Piggy Park Enterprises, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
Publix Super Markets, Inc. and John Easterbrook,
Respondents.
_______________
Maurice Bessinger and Piggy Park Enterprises, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
Piggly Wiggly, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4041
Heard September 13, 2005 â€“ Filed November 7, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
George McMaster, of Columbia and Glen Winston La Force, Sr., of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
C. Mitchell Brown, of Columbia, John Y. Tiller and Elizabeth Applegate Dieck, both of Charleston, Kenneth E. Young, of Greenville, Kevin A. Dunlap, of Spartanburg and Steven Daniel Weber, of Charlotte, for Respondents.
      
    
  

 GOOSLBY, J.:Â  Maurice Bessinger and Piggie Park Enterprises, Inc. (collectively â€œPlaintiffsâ€) appeal the dismissal of their claims against various retail grocers and store managers (collectively â€œDefendantsâ€) filed under the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act (SCUTPA).Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The facts in this appeal are restricted to the allegations of Plaintiffsâ€™ complaint and are assumed to be true for the purpose of our review of the appealed order.[1]Â  
Maurice Bessinger is a native South Carolina businessman and an officer and principal shareholder in Piggie Park Enterprises, Inc.Â  After opening his first restaurant in 1953 in Charleston, South Carolina, Bessinger expanded his business enterprise to include eleven restaurants in the Midlands Area of South Carolina as well as a large bottling and packaging plant for mass production of barbecue sauce and meat for sales in retail stores.Â  Until September 2000, numerous supermarket chains continuously stocked and sold Plaintiffsâ€™ products for between fifteen and thirty years.Â  
In July 2000, after the Confederate battle flag was removed from the Statehouse dome, Plaintiffs began flying a Confederate flag at each of their restaurants.Â  In August 2000, The State newspaper published an article that criticized Plaintiffs for this action and for distributing religious literature at their restaurants.Â  Subsequently, other stories appeared in both print and broadcast media about Bessingerâ€™s political and religious views, with special emphasis on the controversy surrounding the Confederate battle flag.Â  
During the next two months, several retail grocers discontinued selling Plaintiffsâ€™ products and removed the remaining items in stock from their shelves.Â  The only reason these various retailers gave for dropping Plaintiffsâ€™ products was Bessingerâ€™s political and religious views.Â  There was never any allegation that Plaintiffsâ€™ products were unpopular with consumers or of less than the highest quality.Â  The only symbol with any political significance at all on the packaging of Plaintiffsâ€™ products was a small American flag on the labels of Bessingerâ€™s barbecue sauce.Â  
On August 16, 2001, Plaintiffs sued nine corporate entities and several individual store managers in the Lexington County Court of Common Pleas alleging Defendantsâ€™ discontinuation of and refusal to display Plaintiffsâ€™ products constituted violations of the SCUTPA.Â  After filing the original complaint as a joint action, Plaintiffs decided to proceed against the various defendants separately.Â  
On June 21, 2002, the amended complaint was further amended to name BI-LO as a separate defendant.Â  On July 25, 2002, BI-LO moved to dismiss the case under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, for failure to state a cause of action.Â  After oral argument on the motion, Circuit Judge Kenneth G. Goode issued an order on December 27, 2002, denying the motion.Â  His order stated:Â  â€œ[I]t appears to this Court that the Amended Complaint does state a valid claim for relief.Â  Plaintiffs have alleged facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action under the SCUTPA.â€Â  On June 17, 2003, Circuit Judge James Williams filed a consent order permitting Plaintiffs â€œto file and serve a Second Amended Complaint repleading allegations as to damages, after [BI-LO] will be able to respond and plead additional constitutional defenses to the amended complaint.â€Â  Plaintiffsâ€™ amended complaint pursuant to this order was filed July 18, 2003.
The remaining corporate and individual defendants were served with amended complaints as separate actions during July and August of 2003.Â  From August through October 2003, five of the nine corporate defendants[2] and their individual store managers removed their cases to federal court based on diversity of citizenship and moved to dismiss the actions against them under Rule 12(b)(6), FRCP.Â  After a consolidated hearing on October 20, 2003, United States District Court Judge Joseph F. Anderson, Jr., issued an order dated November 20, 2003, upholding the removals to federal court and dismissing the actions.[3]Â  
After Judge Anderson dismissed Plaintiffsâ€™ lawsuit in the federal court, BI-LO moved again to dismiss the state court action under Rule 12(b)(6) in the Lexington County Court of Common Pleas.[4]Â  The remaining state court defendants joined in the motion.[5]Â  On January 6, 2004, Chief Justice Jean Hoefer Toal signed an order vesting Circuit Judge William P. Keesley with exclusive jurisdiction to hear and dispose of Plaintiffsâ€™ state court actions.
Judge Keesley heard the motions to dismiss on March 1, 2004.Â  On March 12, 2004, he issued an order specifically adopting the reasoning in Judge Andersonâ€™s order and ruling that (1) he was not bound by Judge Goodeâ€™s earlier ruling denying BI-LOâ€™s first motion to dismiss because the complaint against BI-LO had been amended in a substantial way; and (2) under the facts as alleged in their complaints, Plaintiffs could not recover under the SCUTPA.Â  
Plaintiffs appeal.[6]
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  We reject Plaintiffsâ€™ contention that Judge Keesley erred in determining he was not bound by Judge Goodeâ€™s order denying a previous Rule 12(b)(6) motion by BI-LO to dismiss the case for failure to state a cause of action upon which relief could be granted.Â  It is clear from South Carolina case law that â€œ[t]he denial of a Rule 12(b)(6) motion does not establish the law of the case nor does it preclude a party from raising the issue at a later point or points in the case.â€[7]Â  BI-LO, therefore, was free to file a second motion to dismiss Plaintiffsâ€™ complaint at a later time.[8]Â  
2.Â  We disagree with Plaintiffsâ€™ argument that they sufficiently pled the elements of an â€œunfairâ€ act to state an actionable grievance under the SCUTPA.
The SCUTPA declares unlawful â€œunfair . . . acts or practices in the conduct of any trade or commerce.â€[9]Â  â€œAn act is â€˜unfairâ€™ when it is offensive to public policy or when it is immoral, unethical, or oppressive.â€[10]Â  
We agree with the trial court that the allegations in the complaint do not suggest Defendants committed acts that would be unfair under the SCUTPA.Â  Assuming without deciding that Defendants terminated their business relationships with Plaintiffs solely because of Bessingerâ€™s statements, there is no First Amendment violation.[11]Â  Moreover, as free market participants, the defendant grocery store chains and their respective managers have the right to choose with whom they conduct their business.[12]Â  Although Plaintiffs are correct that this right â€œis not an absolute, unfettered privilege,â€ recent case law indicates that in South Carolina the enactment of the SCUTPA has not affected this right.[13]Â  Moreover, we agree with Judge Andersonâ€™s statement that, despite Plaintiffsâ€™ assertion that their products were never unprofitable, the business decision to discontinue the sale of these items is best left to â€œthe one who bears the risk of the decision.â€[14]Â  It follows, then, that the courts should not mandate that a private enterprise maintain an association that it believes is not conducive to any facet of its business, including its marketing, public image, and organizational structure.[15]
3.Â  In their brief, Plaintiffs suggest that opinions from the Fourth Circuit supporting an analogous tort claim for the wrongful termination of a distributorship could potentially sustain a claim for an unfair act under the SCUTPA.Â  To the extent this argument was preserved for appeal, we disagree.Â  None of the pleadings before the trial court had any allegations akin to those for wrongful termination of a distributorship, and, notwithstanding authority from the Fourth Circuit to the contrary, this court has observed that no South Carolina decision recognizes a cause of action in tort for termination of a contractual relation in a manner contrary to equity and good conscience.[16]
4.Â  Plaintiffs argue that the trial court further erred when overlooking their allegation that Defendants physically removed from the shelves in their stores those bottles of sauce that had been previously stocked.Â  We find no reversible error.Â  It was incumbent on Plaintiffs to raise this alleged omission to the trial court by way of a post-trial motion.Â  The record does not indicate that Plaintiffs moved to alter or amend the appealed order; therefore, the argument has not been preserved for appeal.[17]
5.Â  Plaintiffs argue the grant of the motion to dismiss was improper because â€œthe case presents a set of novel circumstances that are inappropriate for resolution by Rule 12(b)(6) in an area of unsettled law.â€Â  We disagree.Â  When â€œthe dispute is not as to the underlying facts but as to the interpretation of the law, and development of the record will not aid in the resolution of the issues, it is proper to decide even novel issues on a motion to dismiss.â€[18]Â  Regardless of the assertion that this case is a matter of first impression, the heart of the controversy is the applicability of the SCUTPA to the facts alleged in Plaintiffsâ€™ complaints.Â  As we have explained above, Plaintiffs have not alleged facts to support a cause of action under the SCUTPA; therefore, we hold further development of the record would not aid in resolution of the issues.
6.Â  Because we have determined that the acts alleged in Plaintiffsâ€™ complaints were not â€œunfairâ€ under the SCUTPA, we do not address the rulings in the appealed order addressing the question of whether the allegations in their complaint support a finding that Defendantsâ€™ conduct had an adverse public impact.[19]
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  See Overcash v. South Carolina Elec. & Gas. Co., 364 S.C. 569, 572, 614 S.E.2d 619, 620 (2005) (â€œA motion to dismiss a claim pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, must be based solely on the allegations set forth on the face of the complaint.â€).
[2]Â  The corporate defendants removing the actions against them to the district court were Food Lion, Winn-Dixie, Samâ€™s Club, Wal-Mart, and Harris Teeter.Â  
[3]Â  Bessinger v. Food Lion, Inc., 305 F. Supp. 2d 574 (D.S.C. 2003).Â  The Fourth Circuit affirmed Judge Andersonâ€™s order in an unpublished opinion dated November 19, 2004.Â  On May 16, 2005, the United States Supreme Court denied Bessingerâ€™s petition for certiorari without comment.Â  Bessinger v. Food Lion, LLC, 125 S. Ct. 2270 (2005).
[4]Â  BI-LOâ€™s second motion to dismiss is not in the record on appeal; however, its memorandum in support of the motion was dated January 6, 2004.Â  
[5]Â  These defendants were Publix and the manager of its Lexington County Store, Kroger and the manager of its Lexington County store, and Piggly Wiggly.
[6]Â  BI-LO moved to transfer the appeal from this court to the supreme court on the ground that the case involved a matter of significant public interest and legal principle of major importance.Â  The supreme court denied this motion on June 25, 2004.
[7]Â  Huntley v. Young, 319 S.C. 559, 560, 462 S.E.2d 860, 861 (1995).
[8] Â Furthermore, contrary to Plaintiffsâ€™ argument, regardless of whether Judge Keesley correctly determined that the complaint against BI-LO had been amended in a substantial way, the â€œlaw of the case doctrineâ€ did not prevent him from granting BI-LOâ€™s second motion to dismiss.Â  See 
Lifschultz Fast Freight, Inc. v. Haynsworth, Marion, McKay & Guerard, 334 S.C. 244, 245, 513 S.E.2d 96, 96-97 (1999) (noting the law of the case doctrine â€œapplies only to subsequent proceedings in the same litigation following an appellate decisionâ€).
[9]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-20(a) (1985).
[10] Gentry v. Yonce, 337 S.C. 1, 12, 522 S.E.2d 137, 143 (1999).
[11] See White Peopleâ€™s Party v. Ringers, 473 F.2d 1010, 1015 (4th Cir. 1973) (â€œThere is no dispute that the first amendment protects from state interference the expression in a public place of the unpopular as well as the popular . . . .â€) (emphasis added); Allston v. Lewis, 480 F. Supp. 328, 334 (D.S.C. 1979) (finding a trade publication of the state bar association did not serve as a public forum; therefore, its refusal to publish an advertisement did not constitute a First Amendment violation unless its practices were arbitrary, capricious, or invidious), affâ€™d, 688 F.2d 829 (4th Cir. 1982). 
[12] See McMaster v. Ford Motor Co., 122 S.C. 244, 247, 115 S.E. 244, 246-47 (1921) (â€œ[T]he law allows one to determine for himself with whom he will contract; hence, one may refuse to contract with another or to buy or sell his goods without incurring liability for resulting damage, even though his refusal be prompted by the intent to injure the other.â€) (emphasis added); cf. FTC v. Paramount Famous-Lasky Corp., 57 F.2d 152, 156 (2d Cir. 1932) (â€œA distributor of films by lease or sale has the right to select his own customers and to sell such quantities at given prices, or to refuse to sell at all to any particular person for reasons of his own.â€); Yachting Promotions, Inc. v. Broward Yachts, Inc., 792 So. 2d 660, 664 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2001) (â€œRefusing to do business with a company because of past litigation is not an unfair or deceptive trade practice.â€); PMP Assocs. v. Globe Newspaper Co., 321 N.E.2d 915 (Mass. 1975) (sustaining a demurrer in a lawsuit against a newspaper for allegedly refusing to sell advertising space to a business enterprise providing escort services to the general public, holding that the plaintiff had failed to state facts constituting an unfair trade practice).
[13] See Camp v. Springs Mortgage Co., 310 S.C. 514, 517, 426 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1993) (affirming the dismissal under Rule 12(b)(6) of a claim under the SCUTPA involving allegations by an attorney that the defendant mortgage company had informed a customer that the plaintiff, who had closed several loans for the defendant in the past, was â€œnot acceptableâ€ and holding that the alleged communications by the defendant to prospective borrowers concerning the plaintiff did not constitute â€œan unfair act in the conduct of trade or commerceâ€).Â  
[14] See Dockside Assâ€™n v. Detyens, 294 S.C. 86, 87, 362 S.E.2d 874, 874 (1987) (â€œ[T]he business judgment rule precludes judicial review of actions taken by a corporate governing board absent a showing of a lack of good faith, fraud, self-dealing or unconscionable conduct.â€); Smithy Braedon Co. v. Hadid, 825 F.2d 787, 790 (4th Cir. 1987) (â€œ[A]t least it is safe to say that the most enlightened judicial policy is to let people manage their own business in their own way, unless the ground for interference is very clear.â€) (quoting Dr.Miles Medical Co. v. John D. Park & Sons Co., 220 U.S. 373, 411 (1911) (Holmes, J., dissenting)); Richland Wholesale Liquors v. Glenmore Distilleries Co., 818 F.2d 312, 317 (4th Cir. 1987) (reversing a judgment in favor of a wholesaler against a distributor arising from the termination of a distributorship, holding the termination was supported by reasonable business considerations and noting â€œit is not fair for the courts or juries to second-guessâ€ certain business decisions).
[15] Cf. Americaâ€™s Best Cinema Corp. v. Fort Wayne Newspapers, Inc., 347 F. Supp. 328, 333 (D. Ind. 1972) (upholding the defendant newspapersâ€™ adoption of an advertising policy limiting the content of advertisements from movie houses and other business establishments showing unrated adult films and noting that one reason for the policy was the defendantsâ€™ concern that they would lose their â€œfamily image,â€ which, the court determined, did not reflect an anticompetitive purpose).
[16] Love v. Gamble, 316 S.C. 203, 212, 448 S.E.2d 876, 881 (Ct. App. 1994).
[17] See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (stating that if the trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument raised and the appellant makes no Rule 59 motion to obtain a ruling, the issue is not properly before the court of appeals).
[18] Madison v. Am. Home Prods. Corp., 358 S.C. 449, 451, 595 S.E.2d 492, 494 (2004); see also Brown v. Theos, 338 S.C. 305, 313, 526 S.E.2d 232, 237 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œ[W]hile our courts have held important questions of novel impression generally should not be decided on demurrer, this is not always true.â€), affâ€™d, 345 S.C. 626, 550 S.E.2d 304 (2001).
[19] See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling an appellate court need not review the remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
2002-CP-21-120
Honorage Nursing Home of Florence, S.C., Inc., Appellant,
v.
Florence Convalescent Center, Inc., Respondent.

2002-CP-21-1058
Honorage Nursing Home of Florence, South Carolina, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
Genevieve Powell, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4042
Heard September 12, 2005 â€“ Filed November 14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles Craig Young, of Florence, for Appellant.
Jeffrey L. Payne, of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Honorage Nursing Home of Florence, South Carolina, Inc. appeals (1) the circuit court order vacating the default judgment against Florence Convalescent Center, Inc. (FCC), and (2) the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of FCC.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Honorage Nursing Home instituted this action against FCC for allegedly breaching the lease between the parties for a nursing home building in Florence, South Carolina.Â  In 1975, FCC began leasing the building from Honorage.Â  FCC operated the nursing home from that time until December 31, 2000.Â  
In September of 2000, Genevieve Powell, the President of FCC, informed Howard Clarke, the President of Honorage, that she wanted to terminate the lease and sell the furniture and fixtures in the nursing home to Honorage.Â  Over the course of the next few months, a series of negotiations took place between Clarkeâ€™s attorney, Porter Stewart, and Powellâ€™s attorney, John Chase.Â  The attorneys for the parties ultimately entered into a sales agreement on December 29, 2000, which provided for the purchase of the furniture and fixtures and the termination of the lease.Â  The significant terms of the sales agreement were: (1) Honorage agreed to terminate the lease; (2) Honorage forgave the November and December 2000 rent payments that were due under the lease; (3) Honorage agreed to pay the remaining property taxes for 2000; (4) FCC sold Honorage all of the furniture and fixtures in the nursing home, and (5) Honorage agreed to pay FCC $5,000 for FCCâ€™s computers, printers, and modems, together with all software and information therein.Â Â Â  
On December 31, 2000, in reliance on the agreement, FCC vacated the nursing home and left behind all furniture and fixtures.Â  Honorage took possession and began operating the nursing home on January 1, 2001.Â  
Honorage filed this action on January 25, 2002, claiming FCC had breached the lease agreement.Â  Honorage sought to recover outstanding rent, taxes, and other items due under the lease.Â  Also on that date, Honorage filed a petition to serve FCC pursuant to section 15-9-210(c) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), claiming it could not locate FCCâ€™s registered agent.Â  The circuit court entered an order allowing Honorage to serve FCC pursuant to this statute.Â  However, the circuit court order incorrectly stated Honorage could serve FCC by mail at â€œthe corporationâ€™s last known place of business on record with the Secretary of Stateâ€™s office.â€Â  Section 15-9-210(c) provides the summons and complaint must be sent to â€œthe address of the companyâ€™s principal office which is listed on the last filed annual report of the corporation.â€Â  The last filed annual report for FCC listed its address as 2512 Newcastle Road, Florence, South Carolina, and stated Powell was the sole director and officer of the corporation.Â  
Thereafter, Honorage mailed the summons and complaint to Route 1, Clarke Road, Florence, South Carolina 29501, which was the address listed with the Secretary of Stateâ€™s office.Â  This address was the same address used by Honorageâ€™s own registered agent, Howard Clarke, and it was also the physical address for the nursing home that FCC had previously leased for 25 years.Â  Honorage never forwarded the summons and complaint to Powell or FCC.Â  
After mailing the summons and complaint to its own address, Honorage conducted a default judgment hearing on June 4, 2002.Â Â Â  Honorage also mailed notice of the hearing to the nursing home only and not to Powell or FCC.Â  Neither FCC nor Powell made an appearance at the damages hearing.Â  On March 19, 2002, the circuit court entered a default judgment against FCC in the amount of $1,281,779.Â  The default order prepared by Honorage also contained a finding that FCCâ€™s â€œcorporate veil is pierced and that its sole shareholder is to be held personally liable for the judgment entered herein.â€Â  Powell, however, was not a party to the initial action.
Powell learned of the original judgment when Honorage filed a declaratory judgment action against her to collect the damages.Â  Powell filed a motion to set aside the entry of default against FCC.Â  
The circuit court set aside the entry of default against FCC and also granted FCC summary judgment on the issue of the damages.Â  The circuit court held Honorage had voluntarily terminated the lease as of December 29, 2000, and, therefore, FCC did not breach the agreement.Â  Honorageâ€™s appeal follows. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Default Judgment
Honorage argues the circuit court improperly set aside the entry of default against FCC.Â  We disagree.
Upon motion, the circuit court may relieve a party from a final judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP, where the moving party demonstrates the judgment or order was induced by, among other things, mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect.Â  Hillman v. Pinion ex. rel Estate of Hillman, 347 S.C. 253, 256, 554 S.E.2d 427, 429 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Relief from judgment under Rule 60, SCRCP, rests within the sound discretion of the circuit court, and the circuit courtâ€™s findings will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Thompson v. Hammond, 299 S.C. 116, 119, 382 S.E.2d 900, 903 (1989); McCall v. Ikon, 363 S.C. 646, 651, 611 S.E.2d 315, 317 (Ct. App. 2005) (rehearing denied).
In this action, Honorage clearly failed to comply with section 15-9-210(c) in attempting to serve FCC.Â  Section 15-9-210(c) clearly provides the summons and complaint must be sent to â€œthe address of the companyâ€™s principal office which is listed on the last filed annual report of the corporation.â€Â  Honorage did not do so.Â  FCCâ€™s last annual report was filed with the Department of Revenue in March 2001.Â  This annual report indicated FCCâ€™s address for service of process was 2512 Newcastle Road in Florence.Â  FCC was never served at that address and, accordingly, never received notification of the action against it.Â  Because Honorage failed to comply with the service requirements of section 15-9-210(c), the circuit court correctly set aside the entry of default against FCC.
Additionally, any attempt to serve FCC under section 15-9-210(c) was improper.Â  Honorageâ€™s attorney argued to this court that he was under no obligation to locate FCCâ€™s registered agent prior to service under section 15-9-210(c).Â  We strongly disagree.Â  
â€œA suit at law is not a childrenâ€™s game, but a serious effort on the part of adult human beings to administer justice; and the purpose of process is to bring parties into court.â€Â  McCall, 363 S.C. at 651, 611 S.E.2d at 317 (citing Griffin v. Capital Cash, 310 S.C. 288, 292, 423 S.E.2d 143, 146 (Ct. App. 1992)).Â  Section 15-9-210 (c) is designed to assist a party when a corporation has no registered agent or an agent that could not be served with â€œreasonable diligence.â€ (emphasis added).Â  In this case, Honorageâ€™s attorney informed the circuit court he had complied with the requirements in section 15-9-210, and that he attempted to locate the registered agent for FCC.Â  Yet, Honorage knew the registered agent for FCC had been deceased for almost twenty years because Honorageâ€™s president and controlling shareholder, Howard Clarke, had served as a pallbearer in the registered agentâ€™s funeral.Â  Moreover, Clarke knew Powell was the sole shareholder of FCC as he had known her for over forty years.
Therefore, the circuit court did not abuse its considerable discretion in setting aside the judgment against FCC under Rule 60(b), SCRCP.
II.Â  Summary Judgment
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court:Â  summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 410 S.E.2d 537 (1991).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).
Honorage alleges the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to FCC on the breach of the lease issue.Â  Honorage asserts the lease did not terminate because any agreement to do so did not satisfy the Statute of Frauds.Â  We disagree. 
â€œThe statute of frauds merely requires some memorandum or note of the agreement relating to real estate to be in writing and signed by the party charged therewith or his agent, and does not require a formally executed contract.â€Â  Blocker v. Hundertmark, et al., 204 S.C. 269, 274, 28 S.E.2d 855, 856 (1944).Â  The writing must reasonably identify the subject matter of the contract, sufficiently indicate a contract has been made between the parties, and state with reasonable certainty the essential terms of the agreement.Â  Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 106, 382 S.E.2d 891, 896 (1989). Â 
Porter Stewart, Honorageâ€™s attorney at the time, testified that a letter he wrote in 2001 set forth the sales agreement on behalf of Honorage and Howard Clarke.Â  In this letter, Stewart outlined the terms of the agreement between Honorage and FCC.Â  Moreover, Stewart also testified Clarke had full knowledge of the letter, and authorized the terms of the sales agreement that expressly provided for the â€œtermination of the lease between the parties.â€Â  This letter sufficiently satisfies the requirements of the Statute of Frauds.
Moreover, even if the letter was insufficient, the part performance exception to the Statute of Frauds would apply.Â  â€œSufficient part performance of a parole contract to convey or devise real estate will, in equity, remove agreement from operation of statute of frauds.â€Â  Parr v. Parr, 268 S.C. 58, 65, 231 S.C. 695, 698 (1977).Â  
Here, the parties entered into a sales agreement with one of the conditions being the termination of the lease.Â  Pursuant to the agreement, FCC vacated the premises, and relinquished control over the furniture and fixtures in the nursing home to Honorage.Â  Honorage took possession of the premises immediately after FCC vacated, and remained in possession thereafter.Â  It is clear that both parties have partially performed in reliance of this sales agreement.
Therefore, the circuit court correctly concluded no genuine issue as to any material fact existed regarding the termination of the lease, and FCC was entitled to judgment as a matter of law.
CONCLUSION
For the aforementioned reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s decision to set aside the default judgment against FCC and grant of summary judgment in favor of FCC on the breach of the lease is hereby
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and SHORT, J.J., concur.
