title: Gordon v. Busbee
description: This opinion concludes that a claimant properly made a claim against the estate by filing a complaint with the probate court containing all the information mandated by statute even though a specific probate court form was not used.
text:
Gordon v. Busbee


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Charles E. Gordon, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Clara Gordon Burch,
Appellant,
v.
Jacqueline F. Busbee, Individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of George E. Burch; Dennis E. Burch; and Laurie E. Burch,
Respondents.
In the matter of:Â  The Estate of Clara Gordon Burch
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4044
Heard October 11, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Adele Jeffords Pope, of Columbia and Thomas H. Pope, III, of Newberry, for Appellant.Â  
B. Michael Brackett, Carlos W. Gibbons, Jr. and Deborah Harrison Sheffield, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Charles Gordon appeals the dismissal of his civil action against Jacqueline Busbee, individually and as personal representative of the estate of George Burch, and Dennis and Laura Burch, as devisees of the estate of George Burch.Â  The circuit court dismissed the action because Gordon did not file his claim on a specific probate court form.[1]Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS
On July 30, 1984, Clara Gordon Burch married George Burch.Â  At the time, Clara Burch was seventy-five years old, and George Burch was almost seventy.Â  The couple remained married for nearly sixteen years, until the death of Clara Burch on April 19, 2000.Â  In her will, Clara appointed George personal representative of her estate.Â  She also named Charles Gordon alternate personal representative.Â  
George served as personal representative until his death on January 18, 2003.Â  A month after Georgeâ€™s death, Gordon assumed the duties of the personal representative of Claraâ€™s estate.Â  Gordon claims that after his appointment he discovered various improprieties related to distributions from Claraâ€™s estate.Â  Gordon asserts these distributions were made not only from her estate while George acted as its personal representative, but also from her financial holdings during the time George acted as Claraâ€™s attorney in fact from 1994 until her death in 2000.Â  
Gordon then brought this lawsuit against Jacqueline Busbee, an Aiken County attorney, individually and in her capacity as personal representative of the estate of George Burch, and Dennis and Laura Burch, as devisees under George Burchâ€™s will (collectively Busbee).Â  The summons and verified complaint were filed with the probate court on April 15, 2003.Â  The complaint stated amounts claimed from the estate of George Burch as well as the basis for claiming them.Â  Soon after Gordon filed the complaint, the case was removed from probate court to circuit court, and Busbee answered.Â  
Later that year, Busbee moved the circuit court to dismiss Gordonâ€™s action against the estate of George Burch for failure to present his claim within the proper time and on the proper form.Â  Busbee contended that pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-804(2) Gordon had until the end of the claim period on October 4, 2003 to submit his claim to the personal representative of the estate of George Burch.Â  Busbee argued that because Gordon did not file South Carolina Probate Court Form 371 before the claim period expired, Gordon did not properly present his claim against the estate, and his claim was barred.Â  The circuit court agreed and granted Busbeeâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  
DISCUSSION 
 Gordon raises the following four issues on appeal:Â  (1) whether the trial court erred when it concluded Gordonâ€™s claim against the estate of George Burch was barred because Gordon did not use a particular probate court form to submit his claim; (2) whether the trial court erred when it considered the affidavit of attorney James Verenes; (3) whether Busbee is estopped from asserting Gordonâ€™s claim is barred; and (4) whether Busbee has waived the right to claim Gordonâ€™s claim is barred.Â 
    Probate Court Form 371 is tailored to assist creditors of a probate estate, often unrepresented by legal counsel, when they submit their claims to the personal representative of the estate.Â  The form asks for the name and address of the claimant, the amount claimed, and the basis for each claim.Â  Gordon asserts that the use of Form 371 is not mandatory.Â  We agree.Â  
    The cardinal rule of statutory interpretation is to determine the intent of the legislature.Â  Miller v. Aiken, 364 S.C. 303, 307, 613 S.E.2d. 364, 366 (2005).Â  The intent of the legislature should be ascertained primarily from the plain language of the statute.Â  State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 102, 606 S.E.2d 503, 505 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œThe language must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose.â€Â  Mun. Assâ€™n of South Carolina v. AT&T Communications of S. States, Inc., 361 S.C. 576, 580, 606 S.E.2d 468, 470 (2004).Â  A statute as a whole must receive a practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of the lawmakers.Â  Liberty
    Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 622, 611 S.E.2d 297, 302 (Ct. App. 2005). Â The court will reject a statutory interpretation that would â€œlead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not have been intended by the legislature or would defeat the plain legislative intention.â€Â  Unisun Ins. Co. v. Schmidt, 339 S.C. 362, 368, 529 S.E.2d 280, 283 (2000). 
    Section 62-3-804 outlines two ways in which a claimant may present a claim against a decedentâ€™s estate.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-804 (1987 & Supp. 2004).Â  Section 62-3-804(1) provides that a claim may be presented by delivering to the personal representative a â€œwritten statement of the claim indicating its basis, the name and address of the claimant, and the amount claimed,â€ and the claimant â€œmust file a written statement of the claim, in the form prescribed by rule, with the clerk of the probate court.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-804(1) (Supp. 2004) (emphasis added).Â  Another method of presentation, the one elected by Gordon in this case, is for the claimant to â€œcommence a proceeding against the personal representative in any court where the personal representative may be subjected to jurisdiction.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-804(2) (1987).Â  This action â€œmust occur within the time limited for presenting the claim, and the claimant must file a written statement of the claim as in (1) above, with the clerk of the probate court.â€Â  Â§ 62-3-804(2).Â  
    The standard form frequently filed with the probate court in relation to section 62-3-804 is Form 371.Â  The trial court determined that the language of section 62-3-804 required Gordon to use Form 371â€”and only Form 371â€”because section one, and by reference section two, states that the written statement must be â€œin the form prescribed by rule.â€Â  This interpretation of the statute is too narrow.Â  Section 62-3-804 does not mention Form 371, let alone require the use of Form 371 as the only way to satisfy the requirements of the statute.Â  The phrase â€œ[i]n the form prescribed by ruleâ€ refers to the manner or â€œprocedure as determined or governed by regulation,â€ not to a specific â€œdocument with blanks for the insertion of . . . information.â€Â  The American Heritage Dictionary of The English Language 690 (4th ed. 2000).Â  If the legislature intended to require claimants to use Form 371, it could have easily provided that the claim be brought on the form prescribed by rule, not â€œin the form prescribed by rule.â€Â  Â§ 62-3-804(1) (emphasis added); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-603(B)(2) (Supp. 2004) (â€œWhere a bond is required of the personal representative . . . by law or by the will, it may be waived . . . [if] all known beneficiaries and other persons having an interest in the estate execute a written statement on a form prescribed by the court . . . .â€) (emphasis added).Â  
    Consequently, â€œin the form prescribed by ruleâ€ means in the basic manner set forth in section 62-3-804(1).Â  The purpose of requiring the information set forth in section 62-3-804(1) is to provide notice of claims to the probate court as well as to any party who may have an interest in the estate.Â  While Form 371 certainly provides this information, nothing in section 62-3-804 mandates that Form 371 is the only way this information can be provided.Â  
    Here, the verified complaint satisfies the requirements of section 62-3-804.Â  First, the complaint contains all the information mandated.Â  The complaint identifies the plaintiff/claimant and provides the address of his attorney as his representative in the matter.Â  It further identifies the amounts claimed and the basis for each claim.Â  Furthermore, although the case was removed to the circuit court, the complaint remains on file in the probate court.Â  Because the filed complaint provides notice of claims against the estate to the probate court and any interested parties, making Form 371 mandatory would be duplicative and serve to elevate form over substance.Â  
    Form 371 may be necessary when the claimant intends to submit a claim to the personal representative but does not intend to commence an action against the personal representativeâ€”for example, when the claimant expects the personal representative to allow the claim.Â  Form 371 may also be necessary when the claimant intends to commence a proceeding against the personal representative in a court other than probate court.Â  In that case, Form 371 would put the probate court on notice of the proceeding, which would insure that the estate is not distributed before the claim is handled.Â  In this case, however, the complaint accomplishes precisely what Form 371 is intended to accomplish.Â  Therefore, the trial court erred when it held the requirements of section 62-3-804(2) can be satisfied only by filing Form 371 with the probate court.Â  
    CONCLUSION
    Accordingly, under these circumstances, and in light of the obligation that the probate code be â€œliberally construed,â€ we hold that Form 371 was not mandatory.[2] Â See In re Estate of Tollison, 320 S.C. 132, 136, 463 S.E.2d 611, 614 (Ct. App. 1995) (construing section 62-3-804 liberally to promote the probate codeâ€™s underlying purposes).Â  It is not necessary for us to address Gordonâ€™s remaining issues in light of our disposition of the case.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (citing Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (stating the court need not address remaining issues when determination of prior issue is dispositive)). 
    REVERSED AND REMANDED.
    HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

[1]  We are unable to determine if the order under appeal purports to dismiss the claim against Jacqueline Busbee in her individual capacity.Â  However, because the order is grounded on the failure to comply with a provision relating solely to a claim against an estate, this action appears to have survived the dismissal.
[2]  Because we determine Form 371 was not mandatory, we do not reach the issue of whether the failure to file it has jurisdictional implications.

title: State v. King
description: In this murder case, Appellant posits three issues: (1) whether the circuit judge abused his discretion by refusing to admit a letter co-defendant Patrick Walker wrote to Mesha Thomason allegedly involving statements that were inculpatory of his guilt in killing the decedent; (2) whether the judge abused his discretion by refusing to allow Mesha Thomason to testify, and thereby admit Walkerâ€™s inculpatory letter into evidence since Thomason was present in the courtroom and prepared to testify before Appellant had rested her case; and (3) whether the judge violated Rule 106, SCRE, by instructing the jury to disregard testimony on cross-examination that Appellant gave the police a written statement in which she stated that co-defendant Walker beat her son, that she tried to stop him, and that she sustained injuries.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Earnetta Marie King, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4045
Heard November 8, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â Earnetta Marie King and her boyfriend, Patrick Walker, were jointly tried for the murder of her son, Rodrekus King.Â  King appeals her conviction for murder.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Early March 22, 2002, paramedics responded to a call from Patrick Walker.Â  The call concerned the condition of Rodrekus King, Earnetta Marie Kingâ€™s thirteen-year-old son.Â  When the paramedics arrived, King met them outside and told them her son was not breathing.Â  She escorted them into the house.Â  Once inside, the paramedics found Rodrekus lying on the kitchen floor.Â  He was naked, unresponsive, and pulseless.Â  The paramedics saw Walker attempting to administer artificial respiration to Rodrekus.Â  Rodrekus was transported to Greenville Memorial Hospital, where he later died.
At the time of death, Rodrekus was covered with bruises, small cuts, and â€œavulsed skin.â€Â  An extensive hematoma covered half of Rodrekusâ€™s head.Â  Dr. Michael Ward, a forensic pathologist and the medical examiner for Greenville County, performed the autopsy.Â  Dr. Ward determined Rodrekus died â€œas the result of multiple blunt force injuries.â€
At trial, King blamed Walker for the murder of Rodrekus, and Walker blamed King.Â  King testified Walker was solely responsible for the physical abuse that led to Rodrekusâ€™s death.Â  She claimed she did not hit or in any way assault Rodrekus.Â  King professed Walker repeatedly punched, kicked, and struck Rodrekus with a mop handle and broom.
In support of her assertion that Walker acted alone, King attempted to admit a handwritten letter from Walker to Mesha Thomason, Walkerâ€™s former girlfriend.Â  Kingâ€™s counsel, Walkerâ€™s counsel, and the Solicitor believed the letter to be a confession of the crime by Walker.Â  Because the letter was not divulged to Walkerâ€™s attorney until the day the Solicitor sought to put Thomason on the stand, the trial judge held the State violated Rule 5, SCRCrimP, and excluded the letter.Â  The judge nevertheless allowed Thomason to testify, so long as she did not discuss the statements Walker made in the letter.
Kingâ€™s attorney inquired about his ability to put Thomason on the stand as a defense witness.Â  The following colloquy occurred:

[Kingâ€™s Attorney]:Â  Well, your Honor, I would just â€“ in regard to Mesha Thomason, obviously, we didnâ€™t know [your position] in regard to the Stateâ€™s case.Â  But when the time comes that we have to make a decision whether to put up any evidence, at that point I think what Ms. Thomason has to say is relevant to our case.Â  And while she did not appear on my witness list, because frankly I assumed she was being called by the Solicitorâ€™s office, I would like to have her available to call as a witness in my case.
The Court:Â  Any objection from the State? 
[The State]:Â  No objection from the State.
The Court:Â  [Walkerâ€™s counsel]?
[Walkerâ€™s Counsel]:Â  Certainly I would object to any testimony about the substance of the alleged letter of confession.
The Court:Â  All right.Â  If that happens, the Court will issue its ruling.

The next day, the State rested without Thomasonâ€™s testimony.Â  Because Thomason was unavailable, King attempted to admit the handwritten letter in her absence.Â  The judge excluded the letter based on the Stateâ€™s violation of Rule 5, SCRCrimP, as well as the unavailability of Thomason.
The following day, however, Thomason was available to testify.Â  Before Kingâ€™s counsel rested, he requested Thomason be allowed to testify to the statements made by Walker in his letter to her.Â  King argued:

Your Honor, as we discussed off the record, the witness I intended to call that I indicated to the Court yesterday was not available has now become available.Â  That is . . . Mesha Thomason.Â  She is the witness who earlier in the trial the solicitor had sought to offer because she received a letter from Patrick Walker which was essentially a confession and under ordinary circumstances would be admissible as a confession by him.Â  The solicitorâ€™s office was not able to offer it because the court ruled they didnâ€™t comply with the discovery rules.Â  We donâ€™t believe those rules would apply to us since weâ€™re not the State, and it was certainly not in our control.Â  At this time I would, before closing my case, . . . call Mesha Thomason as a witness and introduce that confession through her.

The judge refused to allow Thomason to testify based on his previous ruling that the State failed to turn the letter over to Walker in contravention of Rule 5, SCRCrimP.Â  The judge concluded Thomason had not â€œshown up in a timely fashion,â€ and, even if she had, her testimony would not be allowed under State v. Fuller, 337 S.C. 236, 523 S.E.2d 168 (1999).Â  King countered that because the letter was a confession by Walker, it was by its very nature exculpatory to King, who would be severely prejudiced if the letter was not allowed to be presented.Â  The trial court refused to admit the letter into evidence.
King was found guilty of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  She appeals the decision by the trial court to exclude Thomasonâ€™s testimony.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002); State v. Staten, 364 S.C. 7, 610 S.E.2d 823 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  A courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error which results in prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 613 S.E.2d 381 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. McLeod, 362 S.C. 73, 606 S.E.2d 215 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Error without prejudice does not warrant reversal.Â  State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 535 S.E.2d 420 (2000).
The decision by the trial judge to exclude evidence for failure to comply with disclosure rules will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  See State v. Kerr, 330 S.C. 132, 498 S.E.2d 212 (Ct. App. 1998); see also State v. Davis, 309 S.C. 56, 63, 419 S.E.2d 820, 825 (Ct. App. 1992) (â€œSanctions for noncompliance with disclosure rules are within the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the decision by the trial judge is based on an error of law.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 540 S.E.2d 464 (2000); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
King argues the trial judge abused his discretion when he refused to allow Thomason, an available witness, to testify.
Initially, we note King did not proffer Thomasonâ€™s testimony.Â  Generally, a proffer of testimony is required to preserve the issue of whether that testimony was properly excluded by the trial court.Â  It is well settled that a reviewing court may not consider error alleged in the exclusion of testimony unless the record on appeal shows fairly what the rejected testimony would have been.Â  State v. Roper, 274 S.C. 14, 260 S.E.2d 705 (1979); see also State v. Cabbagestalk, 281 S.C. 35, 314 S.E.2d 10 (1984) (stating that failure to make offer of proof prevents appellate court from determining whether exclusion of testimony is prejudicial and thus precludes appellant from raising the issue on appeal).Â  However, when it is clear from the record that prejudice exists, the issue will be preserved on appeal despite the absence of a proffer.Â  See State v. Myers, 301 S.C. 251, 391 S.E.2d 551 (1990).Â  The reason for the rule requiring a proffer of excluded evidence is to enable the reviewing court to discern prejudice.Â  Id.Â  That rule has been relaxed where the record clearly demonstrates prejudice.Â  Id.
The record reflects Thomason was going to testify to the statements Walker made in his letter to her.Â  The record clearly indicates King would be prejudiced by the exclusion of Thomasonâ€™s testimony.Â  Therefore, the issue of whether Thomasonâ€™s testimony was properly excluded is preserved for review despite the lack of a proffer.
Rule 601(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence provides: â€œEvery person is competent to be a witness except as otherwise provided by statute or these rules.â€Â  Rule 601(a), SCRE.Â  Generally, â€œ[a]ll witnesses are presumed competent to testify.â€Â  Sellers v. State, 362 S.C. 182, 190, 607 S.E.2d 82, 86 (2005).Â  Courts presume a witness to be competent because bias or other defects in a witnessâ€™s testimonyâ€”revealed primarily through cross-examinationâ€”affect a witnessâ€™s credibility and may be weighed by the finder of fact.Â  State v. Needs, 333 S.C. 134, 508 S.E.2d 857 (1998).
In the instant case, Thomason was available and â€œpresumed competent to testify.â€Â 
See Sellers, 362 S.C. at 190, 607 S.E.2d at 86.Â  Concomitantly, unless a statute or other rule of evidence prevented her from testifying, Thomason should have been allowed to take the stand.
The trial judge determined Thomason could not testify because (1) the State violated Rule 5, SCRCrimP; and (2) her testimony was inadmissible under State v. Fuller, 337 S.C. 236, 523 S.E.2d 168 (1999).
I.Â  Rule 5, SCRCrimP
â€œThe requirements of Rule 5 . . . are judicially created discovery mechanisms for use in criminal proceedings.â€Â  State v. Kennerly, 331 S.C. 442, 503 S.E.2d 214 (Ct. App. 1998), affâ€™d, 337 S.C. 617, 524 S.E.2d 837 (1999).Â  Under Rule 5, the State should disclose to the defendant â€œany relevant written or recorded statements made by the defendant . . . within the possession, custody or control of the prosecution . . . .â€Â  Rule 5(a)(1)(A), SCRCrimP.Â  If the trial judge determines the State has violated Rule 5, the judge has the discretion to fashion a proper remedy.Â  See State v. Salisbury, 330 S.C. 250, 498 S.E.2d 655 (Ct. App. 1998), affâ€™d as modified, 343 S.C. 520, 541 S.E.2d 247 (2001).Â  The judge may â€œprohibit the party from introducing evidence not disclosed, or it may enter such other order as it deems just under the circumstances.â€Â  Rule 5(d)(2),
SCRCrimP.
The trial judge determined that pursuant to Rule 5 the State should have disclosed to Walkerâ€™s attorney the letter from Walker to Thomason.Â  The judge excluded the letter as well as any â€œalleged or purported statementsâ€ made by Walker because the State violated Rule 5.Â  While this exclusion was beneficial to Walker, it was detrimental to King.Â  The Stateâ€™s violation of Rule 5, and the judgeâ€™s remedy, deprived King of the opportunity to admit into evidence an alleged statement from Walker that he alone physically assaulted Rodrekus.Â  The judge, in effect, sanctioned King for the inappropriate conduct of the State.Â  Consequently, King was denied the chance to present exculpatory evidence from an available witness.
A trial judge presiding over a joint trial is charged with the difficult task of maintaining the delicate balance between the interests of the State and the interests of each co-defendant.Â  However, each defendant is entitled to call witnesses whose testimony may exculpate or exonerate them.Â  Therefore, the decision to exclude Kingâ€™s witness because the State violated Rule 5 was an improper and unjust remedy under the circumstances.Â  
On appeal, the State contends the trial court properly sanctioned it for violating Rule 5.Â  The State noted: â€œ[I]t would have been unjust to allow the State to benefit from the violation, regardless of who introduced the letter into evidence.â€Â  The Stateâ€™s argument that Thomason should not be allowed to take the stand because the State would benefit from its own Rule 5 violation is unpersuasive.Â  King claims Thomasonâ€™s testimony would benefit her defense.
Thomason should have been allowed to testify for King even though the State failed to disclose the letter to Walkerâ€™s attorney.Â  The trial judge abused his discretion when he refused to allow Thomason to testify based on the fact he had previously sanctioned the State for a Rule 5 violation.
II.Â 
State v. Fuller
The trial judge refused to allow Thomason to testify because of the South Carolina Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in State v. Fuller, 337 S.C. 236, 523 S.E.2d 168 (1999).Â  Fuller was convicted of murder and conspiracy, and sentenced to life imprisonment without parole for murder and five years, consecutive, for conspiracy.Â  The State presented a statement from a co-conspirator, Holmes, to a third-party, McKinney.Â  The statement was an admission by Holmes that he and Fuller committed the murder.Â  Because the State could not put Holmes on the stand, as he was killed while committing another crime, it put McKinney on the stand and elicited the statement from him.Â  The trial court held the statement was admissible under Rule 804(b)(3), SCRE, which governs hearsay exceptions when the declarant is unavailable.Â  The Supreme Court reversed, holding:

The hearsay statements recounted by McKinney essentially amounted to statements by a deceased third-party that inculpated [Fuller] and subjected the declarant to criminal liability.Â  Thus, the issue before this Court is whether a non-self-inculpatory statement, which is collateral to a self-inculpatory statement, may nonetheless come in under Rule 804(b)(3), SCRE, as a statement made by an unavailable declarant against his penal interest.Â  We conclude that such statements are inadmissible.

Id. at 243-44, 523 S.E.2d at 172.
 Fuller is distinguishable from the case sub judice.Â  First, unlike the declarant in Fuller, the declarant in this case, Walker, is available to testifyâ€”Walker is not unavailable under Rule 804, SCRE, simply because he invoked his fifth amendment privilege against self-incrimination.Â  See State v. Terry, 339 S.C. 352, 529 S.E.2d 274 (2000).Â  Second, Walker, the declarant in this case, does not make incriminating statements about himself and a co-defendant.Â  Rather, the declarant makes incriminating statements about himself only.Â  Walker states in the letter to Thomason that he was solely responsible for the murder of Rodrekus.Â  Thomason can testify to the statements made in Walkerâ€™s letter without violating Fuller because Walkerâ€™s statements are â€œself-inculpatoryâ€ only.Â  This is not a Fuller case because Walker does not inculpate King.
 Bruton v. United States, 391 U.S. 123 (1968), is not implicated.Â  A Bruton violation occurs when two defendants, A and B, are tried jointly, and defendant A makes a confession that inculpates defendant B.Â  If defendant A does not testify, then Aâ€™s statement against B is inadmissible because B will be unable to exercise his right under the Confrontation Clause to cross-examine A.Â  Here, Walker made a confession to Thomason, but did not inculpate King.Â  Thus, Bruton has not been violated.
The trial judge committed an error of law by refusing to allow Thomason to testify based on Rule 804(b)(3), SCRE, and State v. Fuller.
CONCLUSION
We conclude the trial judge abused his discretion when he refused to allow Thomason to testify.Â  Neither Rule 5, SCRCrimP, nor State v. Fuller, 337 S.C. 236, 523 S.E.2d 168 (1999), prevented Thomason from testifying for King.Â  Pellucidly, the error committed by the circuit judge is coupled with prejudice as a matter of law.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is
REVERSED and REMANDED.
 GOOLSBY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
John Bass, Jr., Employee, Respondent,
v.
Kenco Group, Employer, and Zurich American Insurance Company, Carrier,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4046
Heard November 8, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Darryl D. Smalls, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Hyman S. Rubin, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this Workersâ€™ Compensation case, Kenco appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming an award of benefits to John Bass.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In July of 2000, Bass began driving a truck, delivering and installing appliances for Kenco.Â  Bass injured his left shoulder on January 24, 2001 while he and a co-worker attempted to move an 800-pound refrigerator down the ramp of a tractor-trailer.Â  After returning to work, Bass re-injured his left shoulder on March 2, 2001 while unloading a double oven.Â  
Dr. Fulton began treating Bass after the March 2 injury.Â  He placed Bass on light-duty restrictions of no overhead lifting with the left arm, and no lifting of greater than ten pounds.Â  Bass underwent a six-week pain management program.Â  He was eventually released by Dr. Midcap to return to work on a permanent light-duty status.Â  Bass was able to perform office work, but could no longer drive a truck.Â  Due to the sedentary work restrictions, Bass earned only one-third to one-half the salary he made as a truck driver.Â  
In addition to his physical indisposition, Bass experienced anxiety and depression.Â  Dr. Drummond performed a psychological evaluation and declared Bass â€œdysfunctional.â€Â  Dr. Drummond concluded:

the Claimantâ€™s chronic pain was interfering with his life more than normal, that he was suffering from affective distress and feeling of diminished control over his life, and . . . he was evidencing lower overall general activity including social activity, activities away from home, outdoor work, household chores, and a lower repertoire of distracting responses to help him cope with the pain.

Bass was referred to a psychologist, who determined he would be unable to return to work until his symptoms subsided.Â  Bass saw Dr. Estefano, a psychiatrist, who opined Bass had developed severe depression and panic attacks as a consequence of his work-related injury.Â  According to Dr. Estefano, Bass would â€œnot be able to return to work for an indefinite amount of time due to his mental and physical condition.â€Â  
Bass filed a Form 50 seeking an award for (1) permanent partial general disability as a result of injuries to his left shoulder and mental and emotional injuries; (2) past and future medical examination and treatment for psychological and psychiatric conditions induced by the accident; (3) a determination of average weekly wage and compensation rate; and (4) other appropriate benefits under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  
The single commissioner concluded: 

Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-20 John Bass, Jr. has sustained permanent partial disability which has permanently altered his earning capacity from a pre-accident average weekly wage of $1,211.52 to a current weekly expectation of $280, which results in a weekly wage loss of $931.52.Â  Multiplying this figure by .667 equals $621.77 for an accident occurring in 2001.Â  I conclude that the Claimant has suffered this wage loss for the maximum period of 340 weeks for permanent partial disability pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-20.Â  I further find that the Claimantâ€™s partial disability began after a period of total disability and therefore pursuant to said section the amounts paid for temporary total disability shall not be deducted from the maximum of 340 weeks allowed for permanent partial disability. Â 

Additionally, the commissioner ordered Kenco to pay for past psychiatric and psychological treatment and medications, and â€œany continuing causally related treatment and medications for those conditions . . . which tend to lessen the Claimantâ€™s period of disability resulting from his accident-related psychiatric or psychological conditions.Â  Dodge v. Bruccoli, Clark, Layman, Inc., 514 S.E.2d 593 (Ct. App. 1999).â€Â  
The appellate panel and the circuit court affirmed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the workersâ€™ compensation commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981); Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 617 S.E.2d 369 (Ct. App. 2005); Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 599 S.E.2d 604 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify a decision of an agency if the findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions of that agency are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â 
Bursey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health &
Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this Court may not substitute its judgment for that of the appellate panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Liberty
Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 611 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 2005); Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 593 S.E.2d 491 (Ct. App. 2004); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) (2005).
The substantial evidence rule of the APA governs the standard of review in a workersâ€™ compensation decision.Â  Frame, 357 S.C. at 527, 593 S.E.2d at 494; Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 571 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Lockridge v. Santens of America, Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œAny review of the commissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€).Â  Pursuant to the APA, this Courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the appellate panelâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  See Rodriguez v. Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 610 S.E.2d 488 (2005); Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. # 3, 338 S.C. 510, 526 S.E.2d 725 (Ct. App. 2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005); see also Grant v. Grant Textiles, 361 S.C. 188, 191, 603 S.E.2d 858, 859 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œA reviewing court will not overturn a decision by the workersâ€™ compensation commission unless the determination is unsupported by substantial evidence or is affected by an error of law.â€); Lyles v. Quantum Chem. Co. (Emery), 315 S.C. 440, 434 S.E.2d 292 (Ct. App. 1993) (noting that in reviewing decision of workersâ€™ compensation commission, court of appeals will not set aside its findings unless they are not supported by substantial evidence or they are controlled by error of law).Â  Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 272 (2004); Jones v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 586 S.E.2d 111 (2003); Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 562 S.E.2d 679 (Ct. App. 2002); Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 520 S.E.2d 634 (Ct. App. 1999).
The appellate panel is the ultimate fact finder in workersâ€™ compensation cases and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729; Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the appellate panel.Â 
Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 438 (2000); Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366 (1995); Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495; Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729. Â The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 519 S.E.2d 102 (1999); DuRant v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health &
Envtl. Control, 361 S.C. 416, 604 S.E.2d 704 (Ct. App. 2004); Corbin, 351 S.C. at 618, 571 S.E.2d at 95; Muir, 336 S.C. at 282, 519 S.E.2d at 591.Â  Where there are conflicts in the evidence over a factual issue, the findings of the appellate panel are conclusive.Â  Hargrove, 360 S.C. at 290, 599 S.E.2d at 611; Etheredge, 349 S.C. at 455, 562 S.E.2d at 681.
The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 541 S.E.2d 526 (2001); Hicks v. Piedmont Cold Storage, Inc., 335 S.C. 46, 515 S.E.2d 532 (1999); Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495.Â  It is not within our province to reverse findings of the appellate panel which are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Pratt, 357 S.C. at 622, 594 S.E.2d at 274-75; Broughton, 336 S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d at 637.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Efficacy of Kencoâ€™s Assignments of Error
As a threshold issue, Bass argues Kencoâ€™s appeal should be dismissed because (1) its assignments of error â€œfail to meet the standard of specificity required for judicial review,â€ and (2) Kenco asserts an erroneous standard of review.Â  
The circuit court noted that Kencoâ€™s assignments of error all contend the commissionâ€™s findings were â€œâ€˜not supported by the greater weight of credible evidence nor . . . by existing South Carolina statutory or case law.â€™â€Â Â Â  The assignments, according to the circuit court, â€œfail to meet the standard of specificity required for judicial review under the Administrative Procedures Act.â€Â  Furthermore, Kenco erroneously substitutes a preponderance or greater weight of the evidence standard for the appropriate substantial evidence standard.Â  
 Smith v. South Carolina Department of Social Services, 284 S.C. 469, 327 S.E.2d 348 (1985), sets forth the specificity requirement for appeals under the APA:

[A] petition which will suffice legally must be one which will direct the courtâ€™s attention to the abuse or abuses allegedly committed below through a distinct and specific statement of the rulings complained of.Â  In short, the petition must include all that is necessary to enable the appellate court to decide whether the ruling complained of was erroneous. 

Id. at 470-71, 327 S.E.2d at 349.Â  In Smith, the petition for review was â€œbroad and unspecific,â€ and contained â€œno allegation which would explain why [the appellant] believe[d] the agency decision was wrong.â€Â  Id.Â  The Smith court stated, â€œIn essence, the petition merely represents a statement by her that she is dissatisfied with the decision that she received from the agency below.â€Â  Id.Â Â Â  
Unlike the court in Smith, Kencoâ€™s assignments of error are not so opaque or laconic as to hinder our review.Â  Moreover, Kencoâ€™s framing of the alleged errors in terms of â€œthe greater weight of evidenceâ€ is likely an inadvertent scrivenerâ€™s error.Â  This Court is fully cognizant of the proper standard of review to be employed in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases.Â  South Carolina jurisprudence exuberates with precedent extant on the proper standard of review.Â  Accordingly, we decline to dismiss this appeal based on Kencoâ€™s assignments of error.
II.Â  Award of Benefits
A.Â  The Award Under Section 42-9-20
Kenco maintains the court erred in affirming the commissionâ€™s award of benefits under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-20 (1985) because â€œthe facts of this case do not support a loss of earning capacity, since the claimant never was physically fit to drive a truck.â€Â  
Section 42-9-20 provides:

Except as otherwise provided in Â§ 42-9-30, when the incapacity for work resulting from the injury is partial, the employer shall pay, or cause to be paid, as provided in this chapter, to the injured employee during such disability a weekly compensation equal to sixty-six and two-thirds percent of the difference between his average weekly wages before the injury and the average weekly wages which he is able to earn thereafter, but not more than the average weekly wage in this State for the preceding fiscal year. In no case shall the period covered by such compensation be greater than three hundred forty weeks from the date of injury. In case the partial disability begins after a period of total disability, the latter period shall not be deducted from a maximum period allowed in this section for partial disability.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-20 (1985).Â  
â€œUnder our Workerâ€™s Compensation Act, a claimant may proceed under Â§ 42-9-10 or Â§ 42-9-20 to prove a general disability; alternatively, he or she may proceed under Â§ 42-9-30 to prove a loss, or loss of use of, a member, organ, or part of the body for which specific awards are listed in the statute.â€Â  Fields v. Owens Corning Fiberglas, 301 S.C. 554, 555, 393 S.E.2d 172, 173 (1990) (footnote omitted).Â  â€œ[A]n award under the general disability statutes must be predicated upon a showing of a loss of earning capacity, whereas an award under the scheduled loss statute does not require such a showing.â€Â  Id. (citing Roper v. Kimbrellâ€™s of Greenville, Inc., 231 S.C. 453, 99 S.E.2d 52 (1957)).Â  â€œA claimant may obtain partial permanent disability under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-20 (1976).Â  To do so a claimant must show an injury and a loss of earning capacity.â€Â 
Wigfall v. Tideland Utilities, Inc., 354 S.C. 100, 105 n.3, 580 S.E.2d 100, 102 n.3 (2003) (citing Roper, 231 S.C. 453, 99 S.E.2d 52).Â  
Kenco asserts that Bass was insulin dependent while employed as a truck driver, and therefore, he was driving a truck in violation of federal law.Â  Under its theory, if Bass could not legally drive a truck while working for Kenco, he should not be given credit for the salary he enjoyed while doing so.Â  
There is no evidence in the record suggesting Bass drove a truck while insulin dependent.Â  Approximately one month before starting his job with Kenco, a doctor gave Bass insulin shots.Â  Bass testified â€œthe blood sugars kept dropping with the insulin, so I discontinued the insulin and went back to diet and exercise.â€Â  On a Kenco medical history questionnaire filled out prior to being hired, Bass indicated that he did not have diabetes.Â  At the hearing, Bass explained he checked â€œNoâ€ â€œ[b]ecause it wasnâ€™t a major problem, it wasnâ€™t a problem at that time.â€Â  Further, Bass discussed his diabetic incident with Kenco manager Steve McIntire and with the Kenco doctor who performed a physical on him:

  
    
      
        
I told [McIntire] that I had problems with sugar diabetes before.Â  That recently I had had it back in June, a flare up, my wife got sick.Â  When I took the physical I spoke with that doctor and told them the same thing.
        
      
      
        
        . . . .
      
      
        Q: 
        So what did Mr. McIntire
          tell you about that?
      
      
        A:  
         As long as I passed the physical he did not have a problem with that.
      
      
        Q:  
         What was the problem that they had with diabetes in general, according to Mr. McIntire, what was the problem with them?
      
      
        A: 
         Only if I had to go back on insulin would I not be able or be allowed to drive tractor-trailers.
      
    
  

Tests conducted as a part of Bassâ€™s physical came back negative for diabetes.Â  
Bass averred he was not insulin dependent at any time while driving a truck for
Kenco:

  
    
      
Q:Â 
      
      Did you go on insulin at any time when you were driving their trucks?
    
    
      A:  
       Not when I was driving their trucks.
    
    
      Q: 
      No time?
    
    
      A:  
       No time.
    
    
      Q:  
       So at no time were you insulin dependant when you were doing the job for which you were hired?
    
    
      A: 
       Thatâ€™s right. . . .
    
  
The federal regulation pled by Kenco provides:
  
    
      
        (a) 
         A person shall not drive a commercial motor vehicle unless he/she is physically qualified to do so . . . .
      
      
        (b)
        A person is physically
          qualified to drive a commercial motor vehicle if that personâ€”
      
      
        
         . . . .
      
    
  
  
    
      
        
          (3) 
           Has no established medical history or clinical diagnosis of diabetes mellitus currently requiring insulin for control[.]
        
      
    
  

49 C.F.R. Â§ 391.41 (emphasis added).Â  
In essence, Kenco attempts to apply the phrase â€œable to earnâ€ in section 42-9-20 to the average weekly wages Bass was earning prior to the injury, and then argue that he should be deemed unable to earn $1,211.52 because of the diabetes.Â  Yet, according to Bassâ€™s uncontroverted testimony, he was NOT insulin dependant at any time while driving a truck for Kenco.Â  Thus, even if Kencoâ€™s legal theory were sound, it would fail because it is unsupported by the evidence.Â  We reject Kencoâ€™s position that the facts of this case do not support Bassâ€™s loss of earning capacity because he was not actually able to legally earn the income.
B.Â  Award Under 42-9-30 Not Mandated
Indubitably, the record supports an award under section 42-9-20.Â  Consequently, we disagree with Kencoâ€™s argument on appeal that the commission should have entered an award pursuant to section 42-9-30.Â  
In Lee v. Harborside Cafe, 350 S.C. 74, 564 S.E.2d 354 (Ct. App. 2002), this Court explained:

Generally, an injured employee may proceed under either the general disability sections 42-9-10 and 42-9-20 or under the scheduled member section 42-9-30 in order to maximize recovery under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  See Brown v. Owen Steel Co., 316 S.C. 278, 280, 450 S.E.2d 57, 58 (Ct. App. 1994) (proceeding under the general disability sections for an injury to a scheduled member gives the claimant â€œthe opportunity to establish a disability greater than the presumptive disability provided for under the scheduled member section.â€). Only where a scheduled loss is not accompanied by additional complications affecting another part of the body is the scheduled recovery exclusive.Â  Id. (citing Singleton v. Young Lumber Co., 236 S.C. 454, 471, 114 S.E.2d 837, 845 (1960)).

Lee at 78, 564 S.E.2d at 356.
In Stokes v. First National Bank, 298 S.C. 13, 21, 377 S.E.2d 922, 926 (Ct. App. 1988), affâ€™d by 306 S.C. 46, 410 S.E.2d 248 (1991), we held that â€œmental injuries are compensable if, as in heart attack cases, the mental injury is induced either by physical injury as in Kennedy or by unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment.â€Â  Here, the commission found Bass incurred a mental injury as a result of the physical injury he sustained to his shoulder.Â  As found by the circuit court, the commissionâ€™s rulings concerning Bassâ€™s psychological and psychiatric problems

are supported by the unrefuted opinions of the Employeeâ€™s regular physician, his psychiatrist, his psychologist, his vocational expert, and the Palmetto Health Alliance psychologist that the Employee suffered post-traumatic syndrome disorder, that he had an adjustment disorder with depressed mood, that his pain profile classification was â€œDysfunctional,â€ and that these problems were directly induced by the injuries sustained in the accident.Â  The Single Commissionerâ€™s order, adopted in full by the Hearing Panel, quoted liberally and convincingly from the records of those individuals and cited overwhelming support for the ultimate findings of the Commission in regard thereto.Â  Conversely, the Defendants proffered no contradictory evidence whatsoever either by way of APA submissions, cross-questioning of those experts, or deposition evidence.Â  Thus, not only was there substantial evidence to support the commissionâ€™s conclusions but in fact all of the evidence proffered on these points clearly and convincingly supported the Employeeâ€™s contentions.

Dr. Estefano stated: â€œIt is from this [shoulder] injury that Mr. Bass has developed severe depression and panic attack.â€Â  He observed that Bass had â€œdeveloped severe anxiety, severe depression, and excessive amount of pain on his shoulder due to his injury at work.â€Â  Psychologist Patricia Feigley opined Bassâ€™s â€œemotional problems have developed as a result of being injured and unable to work at his previous level.â€Â  In addition, Dr. Stuck declared: â€œI do sincerely believe that the anxiety and stress of his permanent disability and treatment through Workersâ€™ Comp has contributed to his emotional problems that heâ€™s now having.â€Â  These uncontroverted opinions adequately support the commissionâ€™s conclusion that Bassâ€™s post-traumatic syndrome disorder, panic disorder, and adjustment disorder with depressed mood were directly induced by the shoulder injury.
The record fully supports the commissionâ€™s finding that Bass suffered mental problems as a result of a physical injury.Â  Bass incurred two injuries; therefore, the award under section 42-9-20 was appropriate.Â  
C.Â  Origin of Bassâ€™s Psychological and Emotional Problems
In light of the overwhelming evidence in the record, we reject Kencoâ€™s contention that the commission improperly awarded benefits to Bass for psychological and emotional problems.Â  
â€œA mental-mental injury is a purely mental injury resulting from emotional stimuli.â€Â  Doe v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Disabilities & Special Needs, 364 S.C. 411, 418, 613 S.E.2d 785, 788 (Ct. App. 2005) (citation omitted).Â  In order to receive benefits for a mental-mental injury unaccompanied by a physical injury, a claimant must demonstrate the â€œstressful employment conditions causing the mental injury were extraordinary and unusual in comparison to the normal conditions of the employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2004); Doe at 418, 613 S.E.2d at 788.Â  
However, where â€œthe mental injury is induced by physical injury, it is not necessary that it result from unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment.â€Â 
Getsinger v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., 335 S.C. 77, 80, 515 S.E.2d 104, 105-06 (Ct. App. 1999) (internal quotation marks omitted) (emphasis in original) (quoting Estridge v. Joslyn Clark Controls, Inc., 325 S.C. 532, 482 S.E.2d 577 (Ct. App. 1997)).Â  Thus, a mental injury induced by a physical injury is compensable.Â  Doe at 420, 613 S.E.2d at 790; see also Stokes v. First Natâ€™l Bank, 298 S.C. 13, 377 S.E.2d 922 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œA condition, which is induced by a physical injury, is thereby causally related to that injury.â€Â  Doe at 420, 613 S.E.2d at 790.Â  
Kenco asserts that Bassâ€™s emotional injuries were not a result of his shoulder injury.Â  However, Kencoâ€™s contention is not a legal argument, but a factual one.Â  The evidence of record overwhelmingly supports the commissionâ€™s conclusion that Bassâ€™s mental problems were born out of his shoulder injury.Â  The opinions of Dr. Stuck, Psychologist Feigley, and Dr. Estefano all unequivocally link Bassâ€™s psychological issues directly to his physical injury.Â  The commission is the finder of fact.Â  Substantial evidence supports the commissionâ€™s finding.

    III.Â  Credit for Temporary Benefits
The commissionerâ€™s order stated: 

I conclude that the Claimant has suffered this wage loss for the maximum period of 340 weeks for permanent partial disability pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-20.Â  I further find that the Claimantâ€™s partial disability began after a period of total disability and therefore pursuant to said section the amounts paid for temporary total disability shall not be deducted from the maximum of 340 weeks allowed for permanent partial disability.

(Emphasis added.)Â  Kenco argues the commission should have given it credit for the temporary total benefits paid after maximum medical improvement.Â  
The pertinent sentence in section 42-9-20 provides: â€œIn case the partial disability begins after a period of total disability, the latter period shall not be deducted from a maximum period allowed in this section for partial disability.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-20 (1985).Â  
Dr. Midcap released Bass on June 19, 2001 with a 10% permanent impairment to the left upper extremity and placed him on permanent work restrictions.Â  Bassâ€™s depression began as a result of and after this period of temporary total disability.Â  The period of total disability of the shoulder is separate and distinct from the subsequent period of permanent partial general disability stemming from psychological issues.Â  Thus, Bass was paid total temporary benefits only for the uncontested period of his physical disability.Â  Accordingly, the commissioner correctly applied section 42-9-20 and declined to give Kenco a credit for temporary benefits paid.Â  
IV.Â  Maximum Medical Improvement
The commissioner found â€œClaimant has a) reached maximum medical improvement as to his physical injuries; b) has not reached maximum medical improvement with respect to his psychiatric and psychological complications; and c) is in need of ongoing psychiatric and psychological treatment including prescription medications under the direction of Dr. Estefano.â€Â  
Kenco argues that â€œ[p]rior to reaching MMI, the claimant is not entitled to permanent benefits.â€Â  At the hearing before the circuit judge, counsel for Kenco surmised: â€œYou cannot have an order saying that he is partially at MMI and partially not at MMI.â€Â  We disagree.Â  
Kenco has proffered no precedent or rationale demonstrating error in the commissionerâ€™s finding that Bass had reached maximum medical improvement for his shoulder injury but not for his psychological problems.Â  Furthermore, we disagree with Kencoâ€™s statement that Bass should not have been awarded permanent benefits if he was not at maximum medical improvement.Â  A declaration of maximum medical improvement is irrelevant to the award of permanent partial disability in this case.Â  â€œâ€˜Maximum medical improvementâ€™ is a distinctly different concept from â€˜disability.â€™â€Â 
Dodge v. Bruccoli, 334 S.C. 574, 581, 514 S.E.2d 593, 596 (Ct. App. 1999).
â€œMaximum medical improvement is a term used to indicate that a person has reached such a plateau that in the physicianâ€™s opinion there is no further medical care or treatment which will lessen the degree of impairment.â€Â 
Oâ€™Banner v. Westinghouse Elec. Corp., 319 S.C. 24, 28, 459 S.E.2d 324, 327 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  It is true that when a claimant receiving temporary benefits reaches maximum medical improvement and is still disabled, temporary benefits are terminated and the claimant is awarded permanent benefits.Â  Smith v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 335 S.C. 396, 399, 517 S.E.2d 694, 696 (1999) (â€œThe rationale for ceasing temporary benefits upon a finding of MMI is to permit entry of a permanent award.Â  Clearly, if an employee has reached MMI and remains disabled, then his injury is permanent.Â  This is precisely the reason to terminate temporary benefits in favor of permanent benefits upon a finding of MMI.â€).Â  It does not follow, however, that a claimant who has not reached maximum medical improvement is precluded from an award of permanent benefits.Â  
The commissionerâ€™s order documents Dr. Estefanoâ€™s prognosis that â€œâ€˜as long as Mr. Bass suffers from his work-related injury, he will continue to suffer mentally, emotionally, and financially.â€™â€Â  There is no evidence in the record rebutting or contradicting Dr. Estefanoâ€™s conclusion.Â  Therefore, the only evidence in the record indicates Bassâ€™s condition is permanent.Â  The award of permanent partial disability was proper.Â  The evidence supports the finding that Bass had reached maximum medical improvement with respect to his shoulder, but not his mental injuries.Â  Therefore, we find the circuit court properly refused to remand the case.Â  
CONCLUSION
The order of the circuit court is hereby
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Carolina Water Service v. Lexington County Joint Municipal Water and Sewer Commission
description: This appeal arises from a condemnation action and subsequently filed challenge action.  Initially, the circuit court stayed both actions, but thereafter lifted the portion of the stay related to the challenge action.  Appellants argue the lifting of the stay was an abuse of the circuit court's discretion.  We affirm.
text:
Carolina Water


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Civil Action No.: 2001-CP-32-0711 Carolina Water Service, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
Lexington County Joint Municipal Water and Sewer Commission, Respondent.
Civil Action No.: 2001-CP-32-0819 Town of Lexington,
Appellant,
v.
Lexington County Joint Municipal Water and Sewer Commission, Respondent.
Civil Action No.: 2001-CP-32-1527 Carolina Water Service, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
Lexington County Joint Municipal Water and Sewer Commission, Respondent.
Civil Action No.: 2001-CP-32-1534 Town of Lexington,
Appellant,
v.
Lexington County Joint Municipal Water and Sewer Commission, Respondent.
Civil Action No.: 2002-CP-32-0036 Town of Lexington,
Appellant,
v.
Lexington County Joint Municipal Water and Sewer Commission, Respondent.
Civil Action No.: 2002-CP-32-0078 Lexington County Joint Municipal Water and Sewer Commission, Condemnor, Respondent,
v.
Carolina Water Service, Inc., Utilities, Inc., Landowners,
Appellants,
Town of Lexington, Other Condemnee, Appellants.
Unknown Claimants Civil Action No.: 2002-CP-32-0083 Carolina Water Service, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
Lexington County Joint Municipal Water and Sewer Commission, Respondent.
      
    
  

Appeal From Lexington County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4047
Heard September 13, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Clifford O. Koon, Jr., K. Chad Burgess, Paige J. Gossett, John M.S. Hoefer, all of Columbia and Timothy E. Madden, of Greenville, for Appellants.
Joel W. Collins, Jr. and William A. Bryan, Jr., both of Columbia and Nikki G. Setzler, of West Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This case arises out of a condemnation action initiated by Lexington County Joint Municipal Water and Sewer Commission (Joint Commission) to acquire certain facilities owned by Carolina Water Service (Carolina Water) and Utilities, Inc. (Utilities).Â  In response, Carolina Water, Utilities and the Town of Lexington (Town) filed actions challenging the Joint Commissionâ€™s right to condemn these systems (Challenge Actions).Â  Carolina Water then sought to stay the condemnation proceeding pursuant to section 28-2-470 of the South Carolina Code (1991).Â  The circuit court issued an order staying both the condemnation proceeding and the Challenge Actions until the resolution of a related case then pending before the South Carolina Administrative Law Court.[1]Â  At issue in this appeal is the authority of the circuit court to lift that portion of the stay relating to the Challenge Actions.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
This case relates to an ongoing dispute concerning water service in Lexington County.Â  Carolina Water is a private wastewater utility company that owns and operates several wastewater treatment facilities, including the I-20 facility and the Watergate facility, which are the subjects of this litigation.Â  Carolina Water is a voting member on the Central Midlands Council of Governments (Council), which is a regional council of county and municipal governments with various planning responsibilities for the Central Midlands region.Â  The Town is also a voting member on the Council.Â  
Section 208 of the federal Clean Water Act provides a framework for states, through local and regional governmental authorities, to create and implement area-wide waste treatment management plans to control water pollution.Â  Pursuant to federal law, the Governor has designated the Council as the area-wide waste treatment-planning agency for the Central Midlands region.Â  Under state law, the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) has been designated the state agency authorized to implement South Carolinaâ€™s Continuing Planning Process, which must be submitted to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)Â  under the Clean Water Act.Â  The Council is responsible for creating and updating a Section 208 Plan for the Central Midlands region.Â  DHEC is responsible for certifying the Section 208 Plan with the EPA.Â Â  
In 1993, the Section 208 Plan for the Central Midlands region was amended to require the closure of Carolina Waterâ€™s I-20 and Watergate facilities.Â  A 1997 amendment called for the removal of all domestic wastewater discharges into the lower Saluda River and also provided that the I-20 and Watergate facilities be replaced by connection to the Townâ€™s regional sewer system.Â Â  
A dispute erupted between Carolina Water and the Town concerning the financial terms under which Carolina Water would connect the I-20 and Watergate facilities to the Townâ€™s regional sewer line.Â  In 2000, Carolina Water and the Town entered into a compromise agreement which would allow the I-20 plant to continue discharging wastewater into the Saluda River on a permanent basis after expanding the plant to handle 990,000 gallons per day.Â  This agreement was submitted to the Council, which adopted the proposed amendment to the Section 208 Plan and transmitted it to DHEC for certification.Â Â  
DHEC rejected the proposed amendment.Â  Among the reasons for the rejection was the amendmentâ€™s inconsistency with the existing 208 Planâ€™s focus on providing more cost-effective water service by consolidating small, public or private domestic wastewater facilities into larger public, regional facilities.Â  Additionally, the proposed amendment authorized continued discharges into the lower Saluda River, which has been designated as a unique natural resource qualifying for special protections under the South Carolina Scenic Rivers Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 49-29-230(3) (Supp. 2004).Â  Finally, the proposed amendment did not consider alternative proposals that would allow for implementation of the aims of the existing 208 Plan.Â  One such proposal cited was an effort by the Joint Commission to acquire the I-20 facility through its eminent domain power and then to connect it to the Townâ€™s regional sewer line.Â Â  
An appeal was filed with the Administrative Law Court challenging DHECâ€™s authority to nonconcur in the amendment to the Section 208 Plan.Â  On March 6, 2001, however, before the Council adopted the amendment to the Section 208 Plan, the Joint Commission initiated the instant condemnation action to acquire the I-20 and Watergate facilities.Â  Carolina Water, Utilities, and the Town filed the Challenge Actions and moved for enforcement of the automatic stay pursuant to section 28-2-470 of the South Carolina Code.Â Â Â  
On October 3, 2002, after the DHEC case had been heard before the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ), but before the ALJ issued an opinion, the circuit court issued an order staying all proceedings relating to the condemnation action pending resolution of the matter before the ALJ.Â  The circuit court found that the matter before the ALJ, involving the validity of the Section 208 Plan, would control the future use of the wastewater treatment facility at issue in the instant case, and would therefore have a direct impact on the issue of the Joint Commissionâ€™s right to condemn Carolina Waterâ€™s facility.Â Â  
The ALJ subsequently issued an opinion reversing DHECâ€™s decision.Â  The ALJ found that DHEC had no authority to refuse certification of the plan once it was adopted by the Council.Â Â  DHEC was therefore ordered to certify the Section 208 amendment allowing Carolina Waterâ€™s facility to remain in operation.Â Â  The ALJâ€™s decision was appealed to the Full Board of DHEC.Â  
In the interim, the Joint Commission filed a Rule 59(e) motion requesting that the circuit court reconsider its order imposing the stay in the instant matter.Â  In this motion, the Joint Commission argued that the stay order exceeded the bounds of the automatic stay under section 28-2-470 in that it stayed not only the condemnation action, but the Challenge Actions as well.Â  The Joint Commission maintained that the courtâ€™s action was improper because it violated the statutory priority given to eminent domain actions under section 28-2-310(C) of the South Carolina Code (1991), in that final resolution of the Section 208 Plan matter before the ALJ would have no bearing on the Joint Commissionâ€™s condemnation action.Â Â  
In June of 2003, a status conference was held, and during this conference, the propriety of lifting the stay was discussed.Â  Following the status conference, the circuit court decided to dissolve the stay.Â  On February 4, 2004, the circuit court issued an order lifting the stay and allowing the Challenge Actions to go forward.Â  The automatic stay of the condemnation action pursuant to section 28-2-470 remained intact, however.Â  The circuit court also issued a scheduling order on the same date.Â Â Â  
Carolina Water filed a motion to alter or amend requesting the circuit court reconsider its ruling.Â  A motion for restoration of the stay or, in the alternative, for supersedeas was also filed.Â  While these motions were pending, the DHEC Board issued an order reversing the decision of the ALJ. Â Â The circuit court then denied Carolina Waterâ€™s motions.Â  Carolina Water, Utilities, and the Town (Appellants) have appealed from the order lifting the stay.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The circuit court has discretion whether to grant a stay of a matter pending before the court.Â  Talley v. John-Mansville Sales Corp., 285 S.C. 117, 119, 328 S.E.2d 621, 623 (1985); City of Spartanburg v. Belkâ€™s Depâ€™t Store of Clinton, 199 S.C. 458, 480, 20 S.E.2d 157, 167 (1942).Â  Accordingly, the appropriate standard of review is abuse of discretion.Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion arises where the [circuit] court was controlled by an error of law or where its order is based on factual conclusions that are without evidentiary support.â€Â  Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 398, 520 S.E.2d 142, 155 (1999).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The primary issue in this case is whether the circuit court erred in lifting the stay as to the Challenge Actions.Â  However, the Joint Commission raises several preliminary issues relating to the appealability of the stay order.Â  We address each in turn.Â  
I. Appealability of the Stay Order

A. Failure to Provide a Complete Record

The Joint Commission first argues that Appellantsâ€™ arguments have not been preserved for appeal because they failed to provide an adequate record.Â  However, the Joint Commission fails to explain how the record is deficient.Â  Conclusory arguments constitute an abandonment of the issue on appeal.Â  See Solomon v. City Realty Co., 262 S.C. 198, 201, 203 S.E.2d 435, 436 (1974).Â  A reference to supporting authority without any discussion of its applicability is conclusory and constitutes an abandonment of the partyâ€™s reliance on those cases.Â  State v. Tyndall, 336 S.C. 8, 16, 518 S.E.2d 278, 282 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Therefore, this argument is deemed abandoned.Â  

B. Appellants Lack Standing Because They Are Not Aggrieved Parties

The Joint Commission next argues that Appellants lack standing to bring the appeal because they are not aggrieved parties.Â  We disagree.Â  
Rule 201, SCACR, provides that only parties aggrieved by an order may appeal.Â  â€œA party is aggrieved by a judgment or decree when it operates on his or her rights of property or bears directly on his or her interest.â€Â  Beaufort Realty Co. v. Beaufort County, 346 S.C. 298, 301, 551 S.E.2d 588, 589 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
The Joint Commission maintains that Appellants have not been aggrieved by the lifting of the stay because the circuit court lifted only that portion of the stay relating to the Challenge Actions, but left the statutory automatic stay of the condemnation action intact.Â  This argument is without merit because it is the actions instituted by each of the Appellants that the lifting of the stay allows to go forward.Â  In the original stay order, the circuit court found that the matter pending before the ALJ would have a direct impact on the issue of the Joint Commissionâ€™s right to condemn the facility, a matter central to their cases.Â  The resolution of this case in favor of the Joint Commission and the resulting condemnation of the property would preclude Carolina Water from being able to repurchase the property should the DHEC case be decided in its favor.Â  See Indigo Realty Co., Ltd. v. City of Charleston, 281 S.C. 234, 237, 314 S.E.2d 601, 603 (1984) (holding that there is no equitable right of repurchase once property has been taken through the exercise of the eminent domain power).Â  Accordingly, we find each of the Appellants had standing to appeal as aggrieved parties under Rule 201.Â  

C. Standing of the Town and Utilities to Appeal the Order

The Joint Commission further argues that Appellants lack standing to appeal the order lifting the stay because Appellants do not have a property interest in the subject property of the condemnation action.Â  This argument is not appropriate for review because it has not been raised as an issue in the order which was appealed.Â  The condemnation notice named Carolina Water and Utilities as landowners and the Town as an â€œOther Condemnee.â€Â  The circuit court determined in a separate order that the Town had standing to challenge the condemnation action. No appeal of this order was filed.Â  Therefore, this ruling is the law of the case and may not be challenged in this appeal.Â  

D. Interlocutory Nature of the Order

The Joint Commission also argues the order is not appealable because it is an interlocutory order and does not involve the merits.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (1976 & Supp. 2004).Â  In Hiott v. Contracting Services, 276 S.C. 632, 633, 281 S.E.2d 224, 225 (1981), the supreme court found that an order granting a stay was immediately appealable, stating â€œ[i]n this State, a stay is appealable.â€Â  By inference, an order lifting a stay is also appealable.Â Â  We therefore proceed to the merits.Â  
II. Merits of the Appeal
Appellants argue that the order lifting the stay was an abuse of discretion because it was not supported by adequate facts and was controlled by an error of law.Â  We disagree.Â  
Section 28-2-470 of the South Carolina Code (1991) authorizes a landowner to bring a separate action challenging a condemnorâ€™s right to condemn the subject property.Â  That section also provides that â€œ[a]ll proceedings under the Condemnation Notice are automatically stayed until the disposition of the action . . . .â€Â  Id.Â  Consequently, when the Challenge Actions were filed, the Joint Commissionâ€™s condemnation proceeding was automatically stayed by operation of law.Â  However, the circuit court went further in its stay order and also stayed the Challenge Actions pending resolution of the related DHEC case then before the ALJ.Â  
The order lifting the stay in this case did not purport to disturb the statutory stay on the condemnation proceeding, but dissolved the stay only as to the Challenge Actions.Â Â  Therefore, section 28-2-470 is not implicated, and the only question is whether the order lifting the stay prejudiced Appellants in some manner so as to constitute an abuse of discretion.Â  
Appellants first argue the circuit court abused its discretion in lifting the stay because the only thing that happened subsequent to the order granting the stay was the reversal of the ALJâ€™s decision by the DHEC Board.Â  The circuit court cited two pertinent factors in reaching its decision to lift the stay: (1) the long delay in waiting for resolution of the appeals in the DHEC case; and (2) provisions in the South Carolina Eminent Domain Act which assign priority to condemnation cases.Â Â  
A long delay in waiting for resolution of a related case is not a sufficient reason for refusing to grant a stay when conclusion of the proceeding before the court could act as a bar to relief in the related case.Â  Talley v. John-Mansville Sales Corp., 285 S.C. 117, 118-19 n.2, 328 S.E.2d 621, 622-23 n.2 (1985).Â  The Talley court stressed, however, that such a stay is proper only under the most exceptional circumstances.Â  Id.Â  A stay was also found appropriate before the merger of law and equity when the same parties and the same subject matter were involved in both an action at law and a suit in equity.Â  Rush v. Thompson, 203 S.C. 106, 112, 26 S.E.2d 411, 413 (1943).Â  The court held that the equitable suit should be stayed to prevent deprivation of the right to a jury trial on the legal issues.Â  Id. at 112, 26 S.E.2d at 414.Â  It is therefore appropriate to consider whether resolution of the DHEC case will finally determine some aspect of Appellantsâ€™ case.Â  
Appellants argue that resolution of the DHEC case will have a direct bearing on this case, and therefore, the circuit court abused its discretion by lifting its stay. However, as the Joint Commission argued at the hearing, and continues to argue, it plans to condemn the property regardless of the resolution in the DHEC case.Â  The only issue in the DHEC case is whether DHEC has authority to withhold consent to a proposed amendment to section 208 of the Clean Water Act.Â  In the case at bar, the Joint Commission asserts numerous reasons for exercising its eminent domain power, some of which have nothing to do with section 208 of the Clean Water Act.Â  Thus, even if the DHEC case were resolved in Appellantsâ€™ favor, the Joint Commissionâ€™s condemnation action would not be resolved.Â  
Furthermore, section 28-2-310(C) of the South Carolina Code (1991) provides that an eminent domain proceeding must be given precedence over other civil cases for trial if either the condemnor or the landowner so demands.Â  Because the Joint Commission is seeking to expedite the process, the circuit court was within its discretion to consider the need to dissolve the stay to avoid unnecessarily delaying the condemnation action.Â  
Appellants further contend that the stay is justifiable because of the rule announced in Indigo Realty Co., Ltd. v. City of Charleston, 281 S.C. 234, 314 S.E.2d 601 (1984).Â  In Indigo Realty the property owner sold a building to the city after being threatened with condemnation.Â  Id. at 235, 314 S.E.2d at 602.Â  Six months later the city decided not to widen the street, thus negating the public purpose for which the property was sold.Â  Id.Â  The property owner sought an injunction ordering the City to reconvey the property.Â  Id. at 235, 314 S.E.2d at 602.Â  The court refused to do so, holding that creating an equitable right of repurchase would place an unnecessary cloud on the title of property taken through eminent domain.Â  Id. at 237, 314 S.E.2d at 603.Â  
Appellants maintain that under the Indigo Realty rule, if the condemnation action proceeds to a conclusion and the property is taken, they will be deprived of the benefit of a decision in their favor in the DHEC case because they would be unable to repurchase the property.Â  However, because we have found that the Joint Commissionâ€™s condemnation action would proceed even if the DHEC case is resolved in Appellantsâ€™ favor, the Indigo Realty rule is inapplicable.Â  
We therefore find that this case does not involve the type of â€œmost exceptional circumstancesâ€ which would justify a stay that could delay resolution of this case for years.Â  See Talley, 285 S.C. at 119 n.2, 328 S.E.2d 621, 623 n.2.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s reasons for its decision were sufficient to preclude a finding of abuse of discretion.[2]Â  
CONCLUSION
We find the order lifting the stay is immediately appealable.Â  On the merits, we find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in lifting the stay and allowing the Challenge Actions to go forward.Â  Accordingly, the order is hereby 
 AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] By Act No. 202, effective April 26, 2004, the name of the South Carolina Administrative Law Judge Division was changed to the South Carolina Administrative Law Court. 
[2] We further note that the lifting of the stay can be sustained as an act of discretion within the circuit courtâ€™s authority to control its docket.Â  Courts have inherent power to stay proceedings in actions pending before them as part of their power to control their own docket.Â  1A C.J.S. Actions Â§ 244 (2004).Â  The granting or refusing of a stay is discretionary and should be exercised with caution after balancing competing interests.Â  Id.Â
