title: Lizee v. South Carolina Department of Mental Health
description: This is a workers' compensation appeal in which employee was awarded benefits by the Workers' Compensation Commisson, and employer appealed unsuccessfully to the circuit court.  This court joins the circuit court in affirming the Commission's finding that employee is permanently and totally disabled as a result of her work-related injury.  This court, however, reverses the Commission's finding that employee timely notified her employer and remands the case to the Commission for the purpose of determining (1) whether "reasonable excuse" has been made "for not giving [timely] notice," and (2) whether the employer has been "prejudiced thereby."
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Mary Lizee, Employee, Respondent,
v.
South Carolina Department of Mental Health, Employer, and State Accident Fund, Insurance Carrier,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
 Mikell R. Scarborough, Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4048
Heard September 13, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Matthew C. Robertson, Ajerenal Danley, and Cynthia Polk, all of Columbia, for Appellants.
E. Courtney Gruber and R. Walter Hundley, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.: This is a workersâ€™ compensation appeal in which Respondent Mary Lizee was awarded benefits by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lizeeâ€™s employer, the South Carolina Department of Mental Health (the Department), appealed unsuccessfully to the circuit court and now appeals to us.Â  We join the circuit court in affirming the Commissionâ€™s finding that Lizee is permanently and totally disabled as a result of her July 15, 2000, work-related injury.Â  We, however, reverse the Commissionâ€™s finding that Lizee timely notified her â€œemployerâ€ of the injury as required by section 42-15-20 of the South Carolina Code and remand to the Commission for the purpose of determining (1) whether â€œreasonable excuseâ€ has been made â€œfor not giving [timely] notice,â€ and (2) whether the employer has been â€œprejudiced thereby.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (1985).
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Mary Lizee alleged she was injured on July 15, 2000, while working as a nurse for the Departmentâ€™s Crisis Stabilization Unit.Â  Lizee testified that a patient suffering from a severe diabetic reaction was running toward her and began to fall.Â  According to Lizee, she â€œcaught [the patient] and gently put her down on the floor,â€ which caused Lizee pain in her neck and back.Â  
Lizee spoke with two Department employees about the incident on the day it occurred.Â  The first of these was Matt Dorman, a health counselor for the Department.Â  Dorman was part of the Departmentâ€™s â€œMobile Crisis Unit,â€ another mental health facility separate from where Lizee worked.Â  On the day of the incident, however, Dorman was working with Lizee at the Crisis Stabilization Unit on a temporary, â€œfill-inâ€ basis.Â  Lizee described Dorman as â€œanother mental health counselor,â€ and she testified that Dorman had no supervisory authority over her and normally worked at a separate facility.Â  
Dorman was present immediately following the incident.Â  After the patientâ€™s needs had been addressed, Lizee told Dorman â€œwhat happened.â€Â  Dorman suggested she complete a report of the incident.Â  A report was completed, but Lizee was not sure whether she or Dorman filled it out.Â  When asked if she reviewed the report, Lizee stated, â€œI kind of remember and donâ€™t remember.â€Â  Although Dorman delivered a report of the incident â€œdowntown,â€ the record is devoid of evidence that the report contained any reference to Lizeeâ€™s injury.Â Â Â  
Lizee also reported the incident of the patientâ€™s fall to Julie Taylor, the program director for the Crisis Stabilization Unit and Lizeeâ€™s immediate supervisor.Â  Taylor was not working on the day of the incident.Â  However, Lizee telephoned Taylor at her home shortly after the incident occurred and described what had happened.Â  It is undisputed that Lizee did not inform Taylor of the injuries she suffered as a result of the incident, either on July 15 or the following Monday when Taylor returned to work or any other time.Â  
Fourteen months later, Lizee filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim form (Form 50).Â  The Department disputed the claim, contending that Lizee did not sustain a compensable injury and alternatively that she failed to provide timely notice of her alleged injury to the Department.Â  The single commissioner found that Lizee was permanently and totally disabled as a result of the July 15, 2000 incident, and further found that Lizee gave timely and proper notice of the injury to the Department.Â  The Department sought review to an appellate panel of the Commission, which affirmed the order of the single commissioner.Â  Appeal was taken to the circuit court, which affirmed the Commission.Â  The Department now appeals to this court.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  Any review of the full commissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.Â  Bursey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  Accordingly, when confronted with a challenge to a factual determination by the Commission, this courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is supported by substantial evidence.Â  Rodriguez v. Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 84, 610 S.E.2d 488, 490 (2005).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, but is evidence that, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the agency reached.â€ Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 622, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004).Â  Conversely, where the Commissionâ€™s decision is controlled by an error of law, this courtâ€™s review is plenary.Â  Grant v. Grant Textiles, 361 S.C. 188, 191, 603 S.E.2d 858, 859 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting that â€œ[a] reviewing court will not overturn a decision by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission unless the determination is unsupported by substantial evidence or is affected by an error of lawâ€).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Department argues the Commissionâ€™s finding that Lizee is permanently and totally disabled as a result of the July 15, 2000 injury is not supported by substantial evidence and that the Commissionâ€™s findings are not â€œsufficiently detailed.â€Â  We disagree on both counts.Â  The Commission, as the fact finder, found Lizeeâ€™s testimony credible and assigned weight to the opinion of her treating physician, Dr. Donald Johnson, II.Â  As to Lizeeâ€™s claim of injury and disability, the record provides a sufficient basis under the substantial evidence standard of review to affirm the Commission.Â  Moreover, the claim of a deficient orderâ€”in connection with the injury and resulting disabilityâ€”is manifestly without merit.Â  Accordingly, the Commissionâ€™s determination that the July 15 work-related injury rendered Lizee permanently and totally disabled is affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR.[1]
The Department also argues the Commissionâ€™s finding that Lizee provided timely and proper notice of her injury to her employer is erroneous and unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  We agree. 
Section 42-15-20 of the South Carolina Code (1985) initially provides that â€œnotice of the accidentâ€ shall be given to the employer â€œwithin ninety days after occurrence of the accident.â€Â  The claimant bears the burden of proving compliance with these notice requirements.Â  Lowe v. Am-Can Transport Services, Inc., 283 S.C. 534, 537-38, 324 S.E.2d 87, 89 (Ct. App. 1984).
At issue here is the status of Matt Dorman.Â  During oral argument, Lizee conceded that her ability to establish compliance with the notice provision of section 42-15-20 turns on whether Dorman may be fairly characterized as a â€œsupervisor.â€Â  Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 459, 562 S.E.2d 679, 683 (Ct. App. 2002) (construing section 42-15-20 and concluding â€œthat notice is adequate, when there is some knowledge of accompanying facts connecting the injury or illness with the employment, and signifying to a reasonably conscientious supervisor that the case might involve a potential compensation claimâ€) (emphasis added); see also Bass v. Isochem, __ S.C. __,Â  617 S.E.2d 369, 379 (Ct. App. 2005) (noting that â€œ[w]hile the notice requirement must be construed liberally in favor of claimants, it is â€˜not to be treated as a mere formality or technicality and dispensed with as a matter of course.â€™â€ (quoting Mintz v. Fiske-Carter Constr. Co., 218 S.C. 409, 414, 63 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1951)); 7 Arthur Larson & Lex K. Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 126.03[2][a] (2005) (noting that â€œ[g]enerally, in order that the knowledge be imputed to the employer, the person receiving it must be in some supervisory or representative capacity, such as foreman, supervisor . . . .â€ (footnotes omitted)).
In the instant case, Lizee admitted she did not inform her supervisor, Julie Taylor, of the injury she suffered as a result of the July 15, 2000, incident.Â  Indeed, Lizee testified she telephoned Taylor on July 15 to report that an incident had occurred involving a patient, but she did not inform Taylor of any injury she had sustained:

DEFENSE COUNSEL: Now, on Saturday, July 15, 2000, you did call Ms. Taylor at home, correct?
LIZEE: Yes.
DEFENSE COUNSEL: And you told Ms. Taylor that you had caught a patient from falling; is that correct?
LIZEE: Yes.
DEFENSE COUNSEL: You didnâ€™t tell Ms. Taylor that you had injured yourself; is that correct?
LIZEE: Right.
DEFENSE COUNSEL:Â  And Ms. Taylor then came back to work on that following Monday; isnâ€™t that correct?
LIZEE: Yeah.
DEFENSE COUNSEL: And after you called Ms. Taylor on Saturday, July 15, and told her that you had caught a patient falling, you never told her that you had in fact had an accident on the job and that you had injured your back or your neck or any part of your body?Â  You never told her that you injured yourself on Saturday, July 15th, isnâ€™t that correct?
LIZEE: Yes.
DEFENSE COUNSEL: And you never reported that you had injured yourself to anybody else at the Department of Mental Health; isnâ€™t that correct?
LIZEE: Yes.

The only person Lizee purportedly informed of her injury was Dorman, an individual Lizee described as â€œanother counselor at the centerâ€ who Lizee admits did not serve in any supervisory capacity over her.Â  As noted above, Dorman usually worked at another mental health facility and was working with Lizee on a temporary or â€œfill-inâ€ basis on the day of the incident.Â  Indeed, when asked at the hearing who was â€œin chargeâ€ at the Crisis Stabilization Center on the July 15, 2000, Lizee testified she was.Â Â  
After carefully reviewing this testimony and the record as a whole, we find Lizeeâ€™s claimed attempt to notify the Department of her injury does not meet the standard contemplated under section 42-15-20.Â  Under the facts and circumstances of this case, Lizeeâ€™s decision to inform only Dorman deprived the Department of the notice it was entitled to receive under the statute.Â  Generally, a mere co-worker has no duty to report or follow-up on an injury sustained by a fellow employeeâ€”especially in a large, complex organization such as the Department of Mental Health.Â  There is certainly no evidence in the present case that Dorman, as simply â€œanother counselorâ€ from a separate facility, was under any such obligation.Â  The requirement that notice be sufficient to put a â€œreasonably conscientious supervisorâ€ on notice recognizes the fact that those charged with managing and supervising employees bear the responsibility of taking action and informing others in the organizationâ€™s leadership structure of the need to take action to protect the interests of the employee and the organization.Â  The record before us is devoid of any evidence that notice was provided to any supervisor or other person of comparable standing at the Department.
We now turn to the final provision in section 42-15-20 which provides that the failure to timely notify the employer does not automatically defeat a claim.Â  The statute specifically states that the failure to provide notice precludes compensation â€œunless reasonable excuse is made to the satisfaction of the Commission for not giving such notice and the Commission is satisfied that the employer has not been prejudiced thereby.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (1985).Â  In the present case, the Commission did not address this â€œreasonable excuseâ€ and â€œprejudiceâ€ provision of the statute.Â  Lizeeâ€™s entitlement to compensation hinges on this very determination.Â  We decline to make findings in this regard.Â  Gray v. Laurens Mills, 231 S.C. 488, 491-93, 99 S.E.2d 36, 38 (1957) (noting that the Commission is required to make findings on the â€œreasonable excuseâ€ and â€œprejudice,â€ and a remand is appropriate when the Commission fails to make such findings); Harpe v. Kline Iron & Metal Works, 219 S.C. 527, 532-33, 66 S.E.2d 30, 32 (1951) (holding that it is the Commissionâ€™s function to make findings concerning the defense of reasonable excuse for failure to give notice and prejudice to the employer).Â  Accordingly, we remand to the Commission to make findings as to the â€œreasonable excuseâ€ and â€œprejudiceâ€ provision of section 42-15-20.[2]
CONCLUSION
For the above stated reasons, the judgment of the circuit courtâ€”and hence the Commissionâ€”is affirmed in part, reversed in part and the case is remanded to the circuit court, which shall send the case back to the Commission.Â  The Commission shall make specific findings as to the â€œreasonable excuseâ€ and â€œprejudiceâ€ provision of section 42-15-20. The Commission may, in its discretion, take additional evidence to accomplish the remand objective. 
 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL, J. concur.

[1]  We address the merits of Lizeeâ€™s disability claim in the interest of judicial economy and to increase the opportunity for finality on remand.Â  See  Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 26, 602 S.E.2d 772, 781 (2004); Floyd v. Horry County School Dist., 351 S.C. 233, 234, 569 S.E.2d 343, 344 (2002).
[2]  The Department opposes a remand since the claimant relied on having provided timely notice at the hearing.Â  We believe remand is appropriate for four reasons.Â  First, the informal nature of administrative proceedings before the Commission is inconsistent with the exacting procedural hurdles the Department seeks to impose on Lizee and claimants like her.Â  See 82 Am. Jur. 2d Workersâ€™ Compensation Â§ 516 (2005) (â€œInformal proceedings are encouraged in workersâ€™ compensation cases and are so designed that the commission can best ascertain the rights of the parties and prevent unnecessary delays, costly appeals, and rehearings.â€).Â  Second, we adhere to the principle that workersâ€™ compensation laws in general, and notice requirements in particular, are to be liberally construed in favor of claimants and coverage.Â  Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 458, 562 S.E.2d 679, 683 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Third, the Commissionâ€™s adoption of Lizeeâ€™s position on notice removed the need for her to pursue the alternative â€œreasonable excuseâ€ and â€œprejudiceâ€ prong of section 42-15-20.Â  See Harpe, 219 S.C. at 533, 66 S.E.2d at 32 (noting that in cases where timely notice was found there was no discussion of â€œreasonable excuseâ€ or â€œprejudiceâ€).Â  Finally, we recognize that it is not the claimantâ€™s burden to show the absence of prejudice, but it is the employerâ€™s burden to prove the presence of prejudice.Â  Dawkins v. Capitol Const. Co., 252 S.C. 536, 539, 167 S.E.2d 439, 440 (1969) (the burden of proving prejudice lies with the employer).Â

title: The Roof Doctor v. Birchwood Holdings
description: This opinion concludes that an alleged unauthorized practice of law in magistrate's court is a collateral matter not requiring reversal of the judgment rendered.
text:
Roof Doctor v. Birchwood


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The Roof Doctor, Inc., Appellant,
v.
Birchwood Holdings, Ltd., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4050
Submitted October 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005           

AFFIRMED IN RESULT


  
    
      
Bruce Robert Hoffman, of St. Helena Island, for Appellant.Â  
James E. Weatherholtz, of Charleston, for Respondent.Â  
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  The Roof Doctor, Inc. filed this action in magistrateâ€™s court alleging Birchwood Holdings, Ltd. breached a contract.Â  Birchwoodâ€™s answer contained a general denial and a counterclaim.Â  The magistrate entered judgment for Roof Doctor, but reduced the award based on Birchwoodâ€™s counterclaim.Â  The magistrate denied Roof Doctorâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  Roof Doctor appealed to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court ruled that an alleged unauthorized practice of law by Birchwood was not a ground for reversal or voidance of the magistrateâ€™s judgment.Â  Roof Doctor appeals.Â  We affirm in result.[1]Â  
FACTS
Roof Doctor sued Birchwood alleging it failed to pay for roofing work done pursuant to contract.Â  Birchwood answered, counterclaiming for damages allegedly caused by Roof Doctor.Â  Birchwoodâ€™s answer was accompanied by a letter to Chief Magistrate Richard B. Wood.Â  The letter, written by counsel for Birchwood, stated in part:

I have assisted with the drafting of this Answer, but Defendant Birchwood Holdings, LTD has decided to appear for this hearing without representation.Â  As I understand the law, a corporation is permitted to appear and defend itself in Magistrateâ€™s Court without an attorney.Â  In the present case, Mr. Ray Jacobs would like to appear on behalf of Birchwood Holdings, LTD.Â  Please let me know if this will pose a problem.Â  In addition, should you require further proof of Mr. Jacobsâ€™ status as a company employee or specific authorization from Birchwood Holdings, LTD, please notify me at your convenience.Â  

Michael J. McEachern, who signed the complaint as the president of Roof Doctor, was sent a copy of the letter.Â  
Magistrate Kenneth A. Campbell, Jr. presided over the bench trial.Â  In his return, the magistrate found:

Present at the hearing was [Roof Doctor] represented by Mr. Michael J. McEachern and [Birchwood] being represented by Mr. Ray Jacobs.Â  Prior to the start of the hearing [Roof Doctor] raised the issue of the representation by Mr. Jacobs.Â  [Roof Doctor] was given the opportunity to continue the matter to allow [Birchwood] to [r]etain an attorney or authorization.Â  [Roof Doctor] indicated [it] did not wish to have the case continued.Â  

The magistrate found for Roof Doctor, but reduced the award because he found for Birchwood on its counterclaim.Â  Following the magistrateâ€™s ruling, Roof Doctor moved for reconsideration, arguing, inter alia: 

Neither the lower courts nor the parties appearing before them can waive certain rulings of the Supreme Court.Â  Finally, a technical point:Â  Mr. Jacobs was not authorized by Birchwood . . . to represent their interests in the case here.Â  While we went ahead despite this deficiency, it was neither my right nor yours [the magistrateâ€™s] to waive the requirement.Â  This is so simply because the proceeding could never be binding on Birchwood . . . i.e. if the judgment did not suit them, they were entirely free under our Supreme Courtâ€™s ruling in In re the Unauthorized Practice of Law, 309 S.C. 304, 422 S.E.2d 123 (1992), to disavow it.

Roof Doctor asked for additional damages or a rehearing before a jury. Â The magistrate denied the motion for reconsideration.[2]Â  
On appeal to the circuit court, Roof Doctor raised issues of merit regarding the breach of contract action and again raised the issue of Mr. Jacobsâ€™ authorization to represent Birchwood.Â  At the hearing, Roof Doctor abandoned all issues except the issue of Mr. Jacobsâ€™ alleged unauthorized practice of law.Â  Roof Doctor argued that any actions by Birchwood at the trial in magistrateâ€™s court, as allegedly unauthorized, were invalid and therefore Birchwood did not appear at the hearing and the circuit court should enter judgment in favor of Roof Doctor.Â  The circuit court stated on the record:

I think that it is within the Magistrateâ€™s discretion as to decide whether or not the authorization has been properly made, and that . . . on the circumstances of this case, the judgment cannot be collaterally attacked based on the Magistrateâ€™s . . . alleged failure to properly decide this question. 
Once the Magistrate decides that the authorization is proper, that ends it.Â  And . . . secondly, . . . I think thereâ€™s a reasonable basis on which the Magistrate could have found that . . . Jacobs was properly authorized to represent Birchwood. 

In the written order, however, the circuit court merely stated:Â  â€œThe decision to allow Jacobs to represent Birchwood is supported by the evidence.Â  Appeal affirmed.â€Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Roof Doctor argues the order on appeal is invalid because Birchwood participated in the unauthorized practice of law.[3]Â  In support of its argument, Roof Doctor asserts the letter from Birchwoodâ€™s counsel does not satisfy In re Unauthorized Practice of Law, which lists specific representatives that may provide written authorization on behalf of the business entity for non-lawyer representation.Â  Roof Doctor also argues the magistrate did not have the authority to allow the matter to proceed absent such written authorization.Â  
Our supreme court has the constitutional duty to regulate the practice of law in South Carolina and accordingly has the power to define what constitutes the unauthorized practice of law.Â  See S.C. Const. Art. V, Â§ 4; Renaissance Enters. v. Summit Teleservices, Inc., 334 S.C. 649, 651-52, 515 S.E.2d 257, 258 (1999).Â  Modifying the long-standing rule that prohibited non-lawyers from representing businesses, the South Carolina Supreme Court now permits business entities to be represented by non-lawyers in civil magistrate court proceedings.Â  In re Unauthorized Practice of Law, 309 S.C. 304, 306, 422 S.E.2d 123, 124 (modifying State v. Wells, 191 S.C. 468, 5 S.E.2d 181 (1939)).Â  
In allowing the non-lawyer representation, the court mandated:Â  â€œThe magistrate shall require a written authorization from the entityâ€™s president, chairperson, general partner, owner or chief executive officer . . . before permitting such representation.â€Â  Id.Â  The court did not address the issue of a remedy if the written authorization was not obtained.Â  Id.Â  The court has, however, visited the issue of remedies where, unlike here, the unauthorized practice of law constituted part of the underlying contract in dispute.Â  See Linder v. Ins. Claims Consultants, Inc., 348 S.C. 477, 560 S.E.2d 612 (2002).
In Linder, Mr. and Mrs. Linder suffered property loss from a fire at their home.Â  While their claim was being adjusted by their insurance carrier, the Linders consulted a public insurance adjusting firm, Insurance Claims Consultants (ICC), regarding its interpretation of what items should be covered under their policy.Â  The Linders entered into a contract with ICC and requested their insurer deal directly with ICC.Â  After executing the contract with ICC, the Linders released the lawyer they had retained.Â  Id. at 483-84, 560 S.E.2d at 616.Â  When the Linders failed to pay the fee to ICC, ICC sued them.Â  The Linders answered, asserting, inter alia, that ICC engaged in the unauthorized practice of law and the contract between them was void.Â  In addition, the Linders sought damages in tort from ICC.Â  The Linders also filed a declaratory judgment action in the South Carolina Supreme Court.Â  Id. at 485-86, 560 S.E.2d at 617.
The supreme court found that public insurance adjusting did not, per se, constitute the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Id. at 491, 560 S.E.2d at 620.Â  The court found, however, that ICC did more than public adjusting and that some of its activities constituted the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Id. at 494-95, 560 S.E.2d at 621-22.Â  The court found the contract between the Linders and ICC was not void as a matter of law.Â  The court concluded that ICC was not entitled to the compensation for ICCâ€™s services to the Linders that constituted the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Id. at 495-96, 560 S.E.2d at 622.Â  The court stated:Â  

The most appropriate manner in which to sanction [ICC] for [its] transgressions is for the trial court, in the underlying action, to determine the value of [ICCâ€™s] work which did not constitute the unauthorized practice of law.Â  [ICC is] entitled to that amount, but [is] not to be compensated for any amount attributable to [its] unauthorized activities.Â  

Id. at 496, 560 S.E.2d at 622.Â  In considering the Lindersâ€™ claim for damages in tort, the court found no private right of action for the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Id. at 496-97, 560 S.E.2d at 622. 
We need not determine if Birchwood participated in the unauthorized practice of law because we agree with the trial court that the issue of unauthorized practice of law in this case is a collateral matter.Â  Unlike in Linder, the services performed pursuant to the contract in this case are not alleged to involve the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Rather, the alleged unauthorized practice of law occurred during Birchwoodâ€™s defense of the action on the contract.Â  Furthermore, the supreme court dismissed Roof Doctorâ€™s petition of this matter under the courtâ€™s original jurisdiction.Â  We conclude our supreme court has not yet addressed the issue of a remedy in the circumstances present in this case.Â  We accordingly look to foreign jurisdictions for guidance.
In Sawyer Co. v. Boyajian, the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts discussed this issue.Â  5 N.E.2d 348 (Mass. 1936).Â  As we have here, the Sawyer court found it unnecessary to determine whether the alleged improper actions constituted the unauthorized practice of law and stated: 

It may be assumed without decision that the alleged conduct . . . was an unauthorized practice of the law.Â  It is the contention of the defendant, in substance and effect, that the entire proceedings . . . were rendered void . . . even though there was no objection until after a finding had been made.Â  But few authorities support this position. . . . The authorities indicate that proceedings in an action, before any objection is made . . . are not vitiated by . . . [the unauthorized practice of law].Â Â  

Id. at 350.Â  The court also stated:Â  â€œThe case at bar is distinguishable from those wherein objection is made to further proceedings conducted by an unauthorized attorney.â€Â  Id.Â  In this case, although Roof Doctor raised the issue before the magistrate, Roof Doctor agreed to proceed on the merits.
In a similar case, the North Carolina Court of Appeals likewise assumed, without finding, that there was unauthorized practice of law.Â  In re Stroh Brewery Co., 447 S.E.2d 803, 806 (N.C. Ct. App. 1994).Â  The court concluded that dismissal of the appeal on the ground of unauthorized practice of law was not â€œan appropriate remedy.â€Â  Id.Â  The court found the issue was a collateral matter, unrelated to the merits of the appeal.Â  Id.Â  The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals also found a judgment rendered in a case where an unauthorized attorney practiced law is neither void nor subject to reversal.Â  Alexander v. Robertson, 882 F.2d 421, 425 (9th Cir. 1989). 
CONCLUSION
We agree with the circuit court that any unauthorized practice of law before the magistrate was a collateral matter not entitling Roof Doctor to reversal on appeal.Â  We decline to address whether the circuit court erred in finding Jacobs was authorized to represent Birchwood in magistrateâ€™s court.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the order on appeal is
 AFFIRMED IN RESULT.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  Roof Doctor initially appealed directly to the South Carolina Supreme Court.Â  The supreme court issued an order dismissing the appeal, stating â€œBecause these issues can be raised to the lower courts in the course of this action, we deny McEachernâ€™s request to address them in this Courtâ€™s original jurisdiction.â€Â  
[3]  Although Roof Doctor argues the order is invalid, it does not request the order be declared void.Â  Rather, it requests this court reverse and remand for either a new trial or for entry of default.Â

description: In this criminal case, the appellant was convicted of murder.  On appeal, the appellant posits three issues: (1) did the trial court err in admitting evidence of flight; (2) did the trial court abuse its discretion in failing to grant severance; and (3) did the trial court err in admitting testimony of an investigator.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Patrick B. Walker, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
J. Mark Hayes, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4049
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 28, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Susannah Ross, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka and Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Patrick B. Walker appeals his conviction for the murder of Rodrekus King.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On Thursday, March 21, 2002, Earnetta King served dinner to her boyfriend, Patrick Walker, and to her three children: Rodrekus, Brittany and Javario.Â  As the family gathered to eat, King tasted the food and accused someone of â€œadding something.â€Â  After denying that he had added anything, Walker blamed Rodrekus.Â  Rodrekus refuted the accusation.Â  Walker responded by slapping Rodrekus in the head.Â  At that point, King sent Brittany and Javario to their rooms.Â  At 2:15 a.m. on Friday, March 22, 2002, Rodrekus was pronounced dead as a result of multiple blunt-force injuries.
Brittany King was nine years old at the time of her brotherâ€™s death.Â  She testified that after getting sent to her room, she proceeded into Rodrekusâ€™s room to watch cable television.Â  Before long, Brittany observed Walker pushing Rodrekus into the bedroom where she was.Â  According to Brittany, Walker was kicking and punching Rodrekus in the head, back and stomach.Â  Shocked, Brittany watched as Walker hit her brother with a metal broom stick on the left side of his body.Â  Rodrekus, who was naked, begged Brittany to help him, but Walker laughed, told her to â€œshut up,â€ and pushed her away.Â  Finally, Walker ordered Brittany out of Rodrekusâ€™s room, but she could hear the fighting continue as she went to sleep that night.Â  Later, Brittany was awakened by a loud â€œboomingâ€ sound.Â  She went back to sleep but woke up again when she heard ambulance sirens.Â  Shortly thereafter, Kingâ€™s father came to pick up Brittany and Javario.Â  Before they left, Walker kissed Brittany on the cheek and threatened her saying, â€œ[d]onâ€™t tell the police anything.Â  If you do, then Iâ€™ll kill you and your momma.â€
At 12:47 a.m. on March 22, paramedics were alerted that a thirteen-year-old boy had fallen, hit his head in the kitchen, and was having a seizure.Â  By 12:54 a.m., the EMS workers had arrived at Earnetta Kingâ€™s residence.Â  They found Rodrekus unclothed, pulseless, and unresponsive, laying face-up on the floor.Â  A shirtless Walker was attempting CPR.Â  Immediately, the EMS workers prepped Rodrekus for transport to the Greenville Memorial Hospital.Â  At 2:15 a.m., Dr. Allison Jones, an emergency room pediatric physician, declared Rodrekus dead.Â  
As Rodrekus was rushed to the hospital, Deputy Tangie Saylors escorted King to the Law Enforcement Center where she gave her statement to Investigator Paul Silvaggio.Â  King admitted whipping her son with a belt, thick switch, and metal-handled broom because she was upset with him for getting suspended from school.Â  Additionally, King confessed that she was â€œout of controlâ€ and could not stop hitting Rodrekus on his side and shoulder.Â  Because Rodrekus kept moving around as she was hitting him, King accidentally struck his head with the metal handle.Â  King stated Rodrekus fell in the kitchen and hit his head on the counter.Â  At that point, she ran him a bath.Â  As he was getting out of the bathtub, Rodrekus slipped, fell, and hit his head again.Â  According to King, Rodrekus went into convulsions.Â  She asked Walker for help, while she called 911.
At trial, King changed her testimony.Â  King professed that Walker was the sole assailant.Â  When she attempted to intervene, Walker hit her.
Patrick Walker drove himself to the police station after Rodrekus was transported to the hospital.Â  Around 5 a.m. on March 22, Walker issued a statement to Investigator Silvaggio denying any culpability.Â  After Investigator Silvaggio received statements from both King and Walker, he allowed them to leave.Â  Investigator Silvaggio explained that they were not under arrest, but requested that they go home and stay there in case the police needed more information.
On the afternoon of March 22, Investigator Silvaggio attempted to serve Walker with an arrest warrant at his residence.Â  Neither he nor King was home.Â  Over the following weekend, Investigator Silvaggio visited Walkerâ€™s cousin while looking for Walker.Â  Investigator Silvaggio found Walkerâ€™s clothing at the cousinâ€™s house.Â  At that point, Investigator Silvaggio notified the fugitive squad because he feared that Walker could be on the run.Â  Walker turned himself in on Monday morning, March 25, 2002.
Dr. Allison Jones and Dr. Michael Ward were called as expert witnesses for the State.Â  Dr. Jones stated that she and the emergency room staff at Greenville Memorial were â€œhorrifiedâ€ by the number of bruises and cuts on Rodrekusâ€™ body.Â  According to the coloration of the bruises and the absence of any healing, most of the bruises â€œlooked fairly fresh.â€Â  In addition, half of Rodrekusâ€™ back was one big bruise.
Dr. Jones testified in detail regarding the injuries sustained by
Rodrekus:

Large freshly bleeding abrasion . . . with [extensive] scalp hematoma . . . .Â  He also had aÂ  . . . scabbed over abrasion to the top of the left ear . . . . Had . . . multiple scabbed cuts and abrasions over the tops of both of his shoulders, a very linear bruise in the middle of his chest, and an area with some superficial cuts and abrasions with a surrounding bruise.Â  The center area, he had a circular shaped bruise with these two linear pieces off of the edge of that circular bruise.Â  Another one-by-one centimeter abrasion or scrape to the inner surface of his arm, and a bruise with a circular or a crescent-shaped end and two linear streaks extending from that crescent-shaped area. . . . And another extensive massive bruise that had a lot of linear marks that overlapped and were through this area in different directions, indicating that there was some contact with something to make these lines in a variety of directions.
He also had some torn skin with bruised edges, some reddish subcuticular tissue . . . . Another linear bruise [on] . . . the inner surface of his knee, and multiple scabbed cuts and abrasions across the front parts of both of his legs.
  
. . . .
  
This also was another large bruised area that again coversâ€”this is the bottom of his scapula or his shoulder blade, and this . . . is the top of the hip or the top of his buttocks, and the bruise was about half of his back and obviously covered to the midline again. . . .
.
He had another avulsed or torn piece of skin, J-shaped or circular in shape to the top of it with a linear or small cut that . . . appeared to . . . have the same pattern as the bruising on the front, but the skin was torn with a cut from that.
Another small cut to the soft tissue or the fleshy tissue of his buttocks, a three centimeter bruise up here on the back of his right arm.Â  Also interesting was that he had a lot of avulsed, torn skin into his fingers and his hand . . . where the skin looked like it had been torn not cut.Â  He had two side-by-side linear bruises . . . looking much like the pattern on the front that we saw with the lines. . . . [A] bruise . . . took up a good portion of his right side with a lot of that bruising over soft, fatty tissue over the buttocks.

Dr. Jones documented an extensive hematoma that covered half of Rodrekusâ€™s head.Â  The skin on his entire body was torn with bruised edges.Â  When asked if the bruises on Rodrekusâ€™s body would correspond with a fall in the kitchen or bathtub, Dr. Jones answered: â€œAbsolutely not.â€
Dr. Ward, a forensic pathologist and the medical examiner for Greenville County, examined Rodrekus post-mortem.Â  Dr. Ward explained:

[I]n the chest and abdomen region there are multiple contusions and abrasions, or bruises and scratches. . . .Â  This is a patterned bruise of the skin which is often made by a cylindrical object that when it strikes the skin pushes the blood out to either side, causing a parallel type of bruise. . . . So this is here on the left anterior chest or the left front portion of the chest.
There are . . . deep scratches or abrasions on the chest and upper arm here at the shoulder, just to the left of nipple, and overlying the ribs . . . . [T]here was blood within the underlying subcutaneous tissues and musculature of the chest. . . . .

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Down on the abdomen there is a similar, again, parallel contusion of the skin. . . . .

  
. . . .
  
. . . [T]here was hemorrhage in basically three layers as we went down deeper . . . into the body.Â  First, the fat of the large intestine, then the small intestine, and then the deep tissues surrounding the pancreas and actually hemorrhage into the pancreas itself.
. . . [On the thighs], there are . . . patterned contusions or bruises of the skin. . . . All of these . . . injuries [except one] showed no indication . . . that they were old, . . . they all appeared fresh with no healing.
The skin of the buttocks was diffusely bruised, much like the hands and the wrists.Â  And multiple incisions were made into the skin and underlying musculature of the buttocks, and there was a great deal of hemorrhage within the skin and musculature of both sides of the buttocks. . . .
  
. . . .
  
. . . [T]he injuries to the head of Rodrekus were limited to the left side and left back of his scalp.Â  There were three separate distinct injuries . . . . [There was] an area of abrasion or a scratch right in front of the left ear, right at the top portion of the left ear.Â  This is a linear abrasion right here, and this larger wound is a laceration or a tear in the skin, . . . caused by a blunt object with enough force to actually split the skin open or cause a laceration. . . . Rodrekusâ€™ scalp . . . was detached from the underlying bone.
. . . [T]here was a collection of blood [in the scalp] called subgaleal hemorrhage . . . . [O]n top of the brain there was a collection of blood called subdural blood.Â  And then overlying the surface of the brain on the right and left . . . sides and overlying the cerebellum, . . . there was subarachnoid hemorrhage. . . . The brain was swollen . . . .

Dr. Ward found: (1) bruising and hemorrhaging on Rodrekusâ€™s arms, which were characteristic of defense-type injuries; and (2) bruising and abrasions on Rodrekusâ€™ back.Â  When Dr. Ward was asked if Rodrekusâ€™ injuries were consistent with him â€œhaving fallen down in the bathroom . . . and struck his head on the bathtub,â€ Dr. Ward responded: â€œI think it would be inconsistent with that. . . . This is not simply from a fall.Â  This is from multiple impacts to the side of the head. . . . [T]o receive this total constellation of injuries to the head region is not consistent with the fall but from several blows.â€Â  During the autopsy, Dr. Ward was provided with â€œpossible weaponsâ€ to compare to Rodrekusâ€™ injuries.Â  He stated several of the injury patterns were consistent with the â€œpossible weaponsâ€ provided to him: a broom and a belt buckle.Â  When questioned as to how Rodrekus received the injuries to his intestines and pancreas, Dr. Ward opined:

A particular pattern of injury that we see in forensics is a blow with a fairly blunt object, often described as either a fist or a foot, from a punch or a stomp will leave an injury pattern like this. . . . [I]f the abdomen is soft enough or if the musculature of the abdomen is flaccid, then this fist or foot can completely compress the skin in the abdomen and basically squash or compress the organs between the skin and the backbone.Â  And I think thatâ€™s what happened in this case, that the large intestine and its fat were trapped; the small intestine and its fat were trapped; and the pancreas were all basically compressed by this striking object, causing the hemorrhage within that region. . . . It would have to be a very hard blow to cause hemorrhage around the pancreas, which is very deep.

Walker and King were convicted of murder.Â  Both were sentenced to life imprisonment.
STANDARD OF REVIEW 
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Cutter, 261 S.C. 140, 199 S.E.2d 61 (1973); State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 577 S.E.2d 498 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  On appeal, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion.Â  State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998); State v. Bowie, 360 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 540 S.E.2d 464 (2000); State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 582 S.E.2d 426 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).
This Court does not reassess the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence. Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829; State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 S.E.2d 852 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Furthermore, this Court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000); State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Evidence of Defendantâ€™s Flight
Walker claims the trial court erred in admitting evidence of his flight.Â  We disagree.
Flight from prosecution is admissible as evidence of guilt.Â  State v. Crawford, 362 S.C. 627, 608 S.E.2d 886 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 591 S.E.2d 646 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. granted (Oct. 5, 2005); State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 578 S.E.2d 32 (Ct. App. 2003); see also State v. Ballenger, 322 S.C. 196, 200, 470 S.E.2d 851, 854 (1996) (stating flight is â€œat least some evidenceâ€ of defendantâ€™s guilt); State v. Freely, 105 S.C. 243, 89 S.E. 643 (1916) (declaring the flight of one charged with crime has always been held to be some evidence tending to prove fault).Â  Likewise, evidence of flight has been held to comprise proof and signify evidence of defendantâ€™s guilty knowledge and intent. Â See State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 513 S.E.2d 606 (1999); Town of Hartsville v. Munger, 93 S.C. 527, 77 S.E. 219 (1913); Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 591 S.E.2d 405; State v. Brownlee, 318 S.C. 34, 455 S.E.2d 704 (Ct. App. 1995); see also State v. Thompson, 278 S.C. 1, 292 S.E.2d 581 (1982) (finding evidence of flight admissible to show guilty knowledge, intent, and that defendant sought to avoid apprehension), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991); State v. Grant, 275 S.C. 404, 407, 272 S.E.2d 169, 171 (1980) (â€œ[A]ttempts to run away have always been regarded as some evidence of guilty knowledge and intent.â€) (internal quotation marks omitted); State v. Davis, 354 S.C. 348, 580 S.E.2d 778 (Ct. App. 2003) (noting that circumstances of defendantâ€™s flight from police after the attempted traffic stop allowed reasonable inference of guilty conduct).Â  Unexplained flight is admissible as indicating consciousness of guilt, for it is not as likely that one who is blameless and conscious of that fact would flee.Â  See Crawford, 362 S.C. at 635, 608 S.E.2d at 890; State v. Williams, 350 S.C. 172, 564 S.E.2d 688 (Ct. App. 2002).
Flight or evasion of arrest is an issue for the jury to consider.Â  See Beckham, 334 S.C. at 315, 513 S.E.2d at 612; State v. Turnage, 107 S.C. 478, 93 S.E. 182 (1917).Â  â€œIn South Carolina, we recognize that evidence of flight [is] proper.Â  We also recognize that it is oftentimes appropriate for counsel to argue to the jury the inferences growing out of flight.â€Â  State v. Byers, 277 S.C. 176, 177-78, 284 S.E.2d 360, 361 (1981) (internal quotations omitted); see also Grant, 275 S.C. at 408, 272 S.E.2d at 171 (stating that while a jury charge on flight as evidence of guilt is improper, admission of evidence and argument by counsel concerning it are allowed).Â  The critical factor to the admissibility of evidence of flight is whether the totality of the evidence creates an inference that the defendant had knowledge that he was being sought by the authorities.Â  Beckham, 334 S.C. at 315, 513 S.E.2d at 612; Crawford, 362 S.C. at 636, 608 S.E.2d at 891.Â  It is sufficient that circumstances justify an inference that the accusedâ€™s actions were motivated as a result of his belief that police officers were aware of his wrongdoing and were seeking him for that purpose.Â  Crawford, 362 S.C. at 636, 608 S.E.2d at 891.
There is ample evidence that Walker fled his residence after Investigator Silvaggio asked him to stay at or nearby his home.Â  First, Investigator Silvaggio tried to serve the arrest warrant at his domicile, but neither Walker nor King was there.Â  At that time, Investigator Silvaggio searched for Walker at his relativesâ€™ homes, but instead of finding Walker, he found the clothes Walker had been wearing the night Rodrekus was killed.Â  Because of Walkerâ€™s unexplained absence, Investigator Silvaggio was forced to notify the fugitive squad.Â  Although Walker argues he was not aware that he had been charged with a crime and therefore could not have been avoiding arrest, he turned himself into the police on Monday.Â  Moreover, it can be inferred from his sudden disappearance that Walker was either expecting the police to arrest him or he was planning his escape.
In South Carolina, a defendantâ€™s flight is admissible evidence.Â  Thus, the trial judge in the instant case did not abuse his discretion by allowing evidence of Walkerâ€™s flight.
II.Â  Severance
A.Â  Abuse of Discretion
Walker argues the trial court abused its discretion in failing to sever his trial from that of Earnetta King.Â  We find no error.
 Criminal defendants who are jointly tried for murder are not entitled to separate trials as a matter of right.Â  State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d 63 (1998); State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 481 S.E.2d 118 (1997); see also State v. Garrett, 350 S.C. 613, 567 S.E.2d 523 (Ct. App. 2002) (clarifying that codefendants are not entitled to separate trials as a matter of right).Â  A motion forseverance is addressed to the sound discretion of the
trial court.Â  State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 572 S.E.2d 267 (2002); State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 478 S.E.2d 260 (1996); State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 573 S.E.2d 856 (Ct. App. 2002). Â The trial courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Tucker, 324 S.C. at 164, 478 S.E.2d at 26; State v. Prince, 316 S.C. 57, 447 S.E.2d 177 (1993); Simmons, 352 S.C. at 350, 573 S.E.2d at 860.Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  State v. Lopez, 352 S.C. 373, 574 S.E.2d 210 (Ct. App. 2002).
There can be no clearly defined rule for determining when a defendant is entitled to a separate trial, because the exercise of discretion means that the decision must be based upon a just and proper consideration of the particular circumstances which are presented to the court in each case.Â  State v. McIntire, 221 S.C. 504, 71 S.E.2d 410 (1952); State v. Castineira, 341 S.C. 619, 535 S.E.2d 449 (Ct. App. 2000), affâ€™d, 351 S.C. 635, 572 S.E.2d 263 (2002).Â  A severance should be granted only when there is a serious risk that a joint trial would compromise a specific trial right of a codefendant or prevent the jury from making a reliable judgment about a codefendantâ€™s guilt.Â  Harris, 351 S.C. at 652-53, 572 S.E.2d at 273; State v. Dennis, 337 S.C. 275, 523 S.E.2d 173 (1999). Â An appellate court should not reverse a conviction achieved at a joint trial in the absence of a reasonable probability that the defendant would have obtained a more favorable result at a separate trial.Â  Hughes v. State, 346 S.C. 554, 552 S.E.2d 315 (2001).
A defendant who alleges he was improperly tried jointly must show prejudice before this court will reverse his conviction.Â  Dennis, 337 S.C. at 281, 523 S.E.2d at 176; State v. Crowe, 258 S.C. 258, 188 S.E.2d 379 (1972); see also State v. Thompson, 279 S.C. 405, 308 S.E.2d 364 (1983) (noting that for reversal, a defendant who was tried jointly must show prejudice).Â  The general rule allowing joint
trials applies with equal force when a defendantâ€™s severance motion is based upon the likelihood he and a codefendant will present mutually antagonistic defenses, i.e., accuse one another of committing the crime.Â  Hughes, 346 S.C. at 559, 552 S.E.2d at 317; Dennis, 337 S.C. at 281, 523 S.E.2d at 176.Â  The rule allowing joint trials is not impugned simply because the codefendants may present evidence accusing each other of the crime.Â  Dennis, 337 S.C. at 281, 523 S.E.2d at 176; State v. Smith, 359 S.C. 481, 597 S.E.2d 888 (Ct. App. 2004).
The trial judge must act cautiously in allowing a joint trial.Â  Dennis, 337 S.C. at 281, 523 S.E.2d at 176.Â  The judge must carefully consider problems that may arise from a joint trial, such as redacted statements, and must assure protection of each defendantâ€™s constitutional right to confront witnesses against him.Â  Id. at 281-82, 523 S.E.2d at 176; State v. Singleton, 303 S.C. 313, 400 S.E.2d 487 (1991).Â  A proper cautionary instruction may help protect the individual rights of each defendant and ensure that no prejudice results from a joint trial.Â  Hughes, 346 S.C. at 559, 552 S.E.2d at 317; State v. Stuckey, 347 S.C. 484, 556 S.E.2d 403 (Ct. App. 2001); see also State v. Holland, 261 S.C. 488, 494, 201 S.E.2d 118, 121 (1973) (finding trial courtâ€™s cautionary instructions to the jury in a joint trial â€œprotected the rights of each individual appellantâ€).
Walker asserts he should have been granted a separate trial because of antagonistic defenses between himself and King.Â  Each blames the other for the murder of Rodrekus.Â  These antagonistic defenses do not constitute the requisite prejudice.Â  More importantly, the trial judge had discretion to determine whether Walker should have been granted a separate trial.Â  Based on the evidence, the judge determined that separate trials were not needed.Â  Walker is not entitled to a separate trial as a matter of right.Â  We find no error in the trial judgeâ€™s determination.
B.Â  Curative Instruction
Walker alleges he was denied a fair trial based on the cross-examination testimony elicited from Investigator Silvaggio; the self-serving testimony of the co-defendant, Earnetta King; and testimony from the EMS worker.Â  Therefore, he maintains his motion for severance should have been granted.Â  We disagree.
Generally, a curative instruction is deemed to have cured any alleged error.Â  State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 522 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 1999); State v. Greene, 330 S.C. 551, 499 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œIf the trial judge sustains a timely objection to testimony and gives the jury a curative instruction to disregard the testimony, the error is deemed to be cured.â€Â  State v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 476 S.E.2d 903 (1996); State v. Craig, 267 S.C. 262, 227 S.E.2d 306 (1976); State v. McCord, 349 S.C. 477, 562 S.E.2d 689 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  A curative instruction to disregard incompetent evidence and not to consider it during deliberation is deemed to have cured any alleged error in its admission.Â  See State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d 63 (1998); State v. Jones, 325 S.C. 310, 479 S.E.2d 517 (Ct. App. 1996).
Because a trial courtâ€™s curative instruction is considered to cure any error regarding improper testimony, a party must contemporaneously object to a curative instruction as insufficient or move for a mistrial to preserve an issue for review.Â  George, 323 S.C. at 510, 476 S.E.2d at 912; Patterson, 337 S.C. at 226, 522 S.E.2d at 850.Â  Therefore, this issue may not be preserved for review because the trial court sustained defense counselâ€™s objections and gave a thorough curative instruction without objection or request for a mistrial.
Assuming arguendo the issue is preserved, adverting to the merits in the case sub judice, on four separate occasions the judge gave a curative instruction to the members of the jury.Â  Each time, the curative instruction was timely and complete.
As Investigator Silvaggio was being questioned, the judge determined that a question and an answer were both inappropriate and should be stricken from the record.Â  The judge elucidated:

[T]here was a question that was asked of this witness and the response was given by the witness.Â  The question was: â€œdo you remember what she said?â€Â  And the response was: â€œShe indicated that Patrick Walker was the one that was beating Rodrekus and that she was trying to intervene in the assault between Patrick Walker and Rodrekus.Â  As a result of that, she too sustained injuries to her head, and that Patrick Walker was the sole assailant in the case.â€ . . . I have made a ruling that that question as well as the response was inappropriate at that stage and, therefore, you will disregard that question and also the witnessâ€™s response.

During Kingâ€™s testimony, the judge properly gave a curative instruction: â€œPrior to the break in the testimony, the defendant made an unsolicited statement about some prior bad acts of Mr. Walker, and I will instruct you and you are ordered that you will disregard that statement by this defendant, and you are not to consider that statement in any form during your deliberations.â€
The EMS worker testified regarding Walkerâ€™s intimidating demeanor.Â  Immediately, the judge charged: â€œI ask the jury be instructed to disregard. You may disregard the last statement by the witness.â€Â  Prior to deliberations, the judge instructed:

As the trial judge it is my responsibility to preside over the trial of this case.Â  And I have also the duty to rule on the admissibility of evidence offered during this trial.Â  You are to consider only the competent evidence before you.Â  If there was any testimony offered stricken from the record in this case during this trial, you must disregard that testimony.Â  You are to consider only the testimony which has been presented from this witness stand, any evidence which has been made part of the record in this case and any stipulations of counsel.

In compliance with the law extant on curative instructions, the trial judge responded with alacrity and exactitude when the inadmissible evidence was offered.Â  The potency of the judgeâ€™s curative instructions expunged and extirpated any alleged error.Â  Concomitantly, the motion for severance was properly denied.
C.Â  Closing Argument
Walker contends improper statements made by the co-defendantâ€™s attorney during closing argument deprived him of a fair trial.Â  Thus, he claims his motion for severance was erroneously denied.
Initially, we note this issue may not be preserved for appellate review.Â  An issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.Â  See State v. Weik, 356 S.C. 76, 587 S.E.2d 683 (2002); State v. Carlson, 363 S.C. 586, 611 S.E.2d 283 (Ct. App. 2005); see also State v. Passmore, 363 S.C. 568, 611 S.E.2d 273 (Ct. App. 2005) (instructing that general rule of issue preservation states that if issue was not raised and ruled upon below, it will not be considered for first time on appeal).Â  Failure to object to comments made during argument precludes appellate review of the issue.Â  Carlson, 363 S.C. at 606, 611 S.E.2d at 293; State v. Varvil, 338 S.C. 335, 526 S.E.2d 248
(Ct. App. 2000).Â  Walker did not contemporaneously object to the comments made by co-defendantâ€™s counsel during closing argument.Â  Consequently, this issue is not preserved.
III.Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction
Walker claims the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction due to a faulty indictment.Â  We disagree.
In State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005), our Supreme Court edified:

[I]f an indictment is challenged as insufficient or defective, the defendant must raise that issue before the jury is sworn and not afterwards.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-90 (2003) (â€œEvery objection to any indictment for any defect apparent on the face thereof shall be taken by demurrer or on motion to quash such indictment before the jury shall be sworn and not afterwards.â€).Â  However, a defendant may for the first time on appeal raise the issue of the trial courtâ€™s jurisdiction to try the class of case of which the defendant was convicted.
  
. . . .
  
The indictment is a notice document.Â  A challenge to the indictment on the ground of insufficiency must be made before the jury is sworn as provided by Â§ 17-19-90.Â  If the objection is timely made, the circuit court should judge the sufficiency of the indictment by determining whether (1) the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead an acquittal or conviction thereon; and (2) whether it apprises the defendant of the elements of the offense that is intended to be charged.Â  In determining whether an indictment meets the sufficiency standard, the court must look at the indictment with a practical eye in view of all the surrounding circumstances.Â  Further, whether the indictment could be more definite or certain is irrelevant. 

Id. at 101-03, 610 S.E.2d at 499-500 (internal citations and footnote omitted).Â Â  
There was no challenge to the indictment prior to the jury being sworn. Based on Gentry, because Walker did not raise the sufficiency of the indictment before the jury was sworn, he cannot now raise this issue on appeal.Â  The issue is not preserved for our review.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, Walkerâ€™s conviction and sentence are
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

description: In this workers' compensation action, the issue is whether an order by the full commission remanding the case to the single commissioner for a de novo hearing is appealable, and whether unchallenged findings may be reheard at the de novo hearing.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Sharon L. Brunson, Appellant,
v.
American Koyo Bearings, Employer, and Tokio Marine and Fire Ins. Co., Carrier,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4051
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 28, 2005

 APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Vernon F. Dunbar, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Andrea Pope, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This is an appeal from an interlocutory order of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  American Koyo Bearings and its insurance carrier, Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company, (collectively â€œEmployerâ€) appealed from an adverse ruling of the single commissioner to an appellate panel of the Commission.Â  The Commission vacated the single commissionerâ€™s order and remanded for a de novo hearing.Â  The claimant, Sharon Brunson, appealed from the Commissionâ€™s remand order to the circuit court, which dismissed the appeal as interlocutory.Â  We find this interlocutory order is not immediately appealable and join the circuit court in dismissing the appeal. 
FACTS / PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Brunson worked for American Koyo Bearings for approximately three years on an assembly lineâ€”where she was exposed to chemicalsâ€”sorting and cleaning parts.Â  Brunson filed a Form 50 claiming that she developed contact dermatitis to her hands, arms, and other body parts as a consequence of her employment duties.Â  She further contended that she sustained injuries to her lungs, throat, voice box, vocal cords, nasal passages, and head arising from the scope of her employment.Â  
In response, Employer filed a Form 51 admitting that Brunson suffered from contact dermatitis, and further acknowledging the injury was compensable.Â  However, Employer denied any permanent impairment and further denied injury to the other body parts.Â  
The single commissioner determined that Brunson sustained multiple injuries by accident in the course of her employment, including the finding that Brunson suffered or contracted an occupational disease with respect to her dermatitis and respiratory problems.Â  As a result, Employer was ordered to pay temporary total disability benefits plus all causally related medical treatment and treatment recommended by Brunsonâ€™s physicians.Â  
Employer sought review by the Commission.Â  In its application for review and supporting memorandum, Employer did not challenge the compensability of the contact dermatitis. Â Â Â The Commission vacated the single commissionerâ€™s order and remanded for a de novo hearing.Â  
Brunson appealed to the circuit court, arguing that certain findings made by the single commissioner were not cited as grounds for appeal and consequently should not be revisited on remand.Â  The circuit court ruled the Commissionâ€™s order interlocutory and not immediately appealable on the basis that the remand order neither affected the merits nor deprived Brunson of a substantial right.Â  The appeal was therefore dismissed.Â  We are now presented with the appealability of the Commissionâ€™s interlocutory order and Brunsonâ€™s claim that the Commissionâ€™s order affected her substantial rights.Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
South Carolina adheres to the final judgment rule.Â  Accordingly, with certain exceptions, an appeal lies only from a final judgment.Â  Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 194-195, 607 S.E.2d 707, 708 (2005); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(1) (1976 and Supp. 2004); Rule 72, SCRCP; Rule 201(a), SCACR.Â  By statute, an appeal from an interlocutory order is permitted in certain circumstances, including when the order is one â€œinvolving the merits . . . [or] affecting a substantial right.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(1) and (2).Â  Appeals from administrative bodies, such as the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, follow the same rules, such that an appeal will not lie from an interlocutory order of the Commission unless the order affects the merits or deprives the appellant of a substantial right.[1]Â  Green v. City of Columbia, 311 S.C. 78, 79-80, 427 S.E.2d 685, 687 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Orders from the Commission remanding a case to the single commissioner for further proceedings generally do not affect the merits and are not considered final.Â  Chastain v. Spartan Mills, 228 S.C. 61, 65-67, 88 S.E.2d 836, 837-38 (1955).Â  
Brunsonâ€™s claim of â€œsubstantial rightâ€ springs from the fact that Employer admitted the compensability of the contact dermatitis injury and took no exception to this ruling in the appeal to the Commission.Â  Brunson apparently believes the de novo hearing before the single commissioner includes all issues, including those not challenged in Employerâ€™s appeal to the Commission.Â  Brunson, however, is not required to relitigate unchallenged findingsâ€”which are the law of the caseâ€”including Employerâ€™s admission in connection with the contact dermatitis injury.Â  â€œThe findings of fact and law by the hearing commissioner become and are the law of the case, unless within the scope of the appellantâ€™s exception to the full commission . . . .â€Â  Green, 311 S.C. at 80, 427 S.E.2d at 687.Â  â€œOnly issues within the application for review under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-50 (1976) are preserved for appeal to the commission.â€Â  Id.Â  
Employer candidly acknowledges in the final brief that remand to the single commissioner is limited to the â€œcontested issues.â€Â  See Sellers v. Pinedale Residential Ctr., 350 S.C. 183, 189 n.1, 564 S.E.2d 694, 697 n.1 (Ct. App. 2002) (stating that any issues not argued in the brief are deemed abandoned).Â  As concerns the admitted injury, Employer concedes as follows:

The contact dermatitis was admitted by the employer.Â  Nothing in the full commissionâ€™s order or the circuit courtâ€™s order alters or eliminates that admission. Because the employer admits the contact dermatitis is compensable, the claimant may request medical treatment at any time from the employer.Â  Therefore, any unappealed finding regarding medical treatment or the compensability of the contact dermatitis does not affect the remand because it is already admitted.

Respondentsâ€™ final brief at 10. 
In light of the Commissionâ€™s regrettably conclusory remand order, Brunsonâ€™s reliance on Green v. City of Columbia is understandable, but nevertheless misplaced.Â  There, the single commissioner required the employee to make an election of remedies under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, and the employee did not object.Â  Green, 311 S.C. at 79, 427 S.E.2d at 686.Â  The employee made the election, and the single commissioner denied benefits.Â  Id.Â  An appeal was made to the Commission, but no challenge was lodged with respect to election of remedies.Â  The Commission, sua sponte, held the election requirement to be erroneous.Â  Id.Â  The Commission affirmed the denial of benefits but remanded the case for a hearing to determine if benefits were due under the other, previously abandoned claim.Â  Id.Â  The circuit court dismissed the appeal, finding the order interlocutory and not immediately appealable.Â  Green, 311 S.C. at 79, 427 S.E.2d at 687.Â Â Â Â Â  
We reversed and held the Commissionâ€™s error in reaching an issue not raised in the application for review affected the merits.Â  Green, 311 S.C. at 80, 427 S.E.2d at 687.Â  We therefore found the remand order immediately appealable.Â  
Here, unlike Green, the Commission did not rule on any issue, but merely entered a remand order for a de novo hearing.Â  Since the Commissionâ€™s authority, by operation of law, extends only to those issues within the application for review, the hearing on remand is similarly restricted.Â  In short, the compensability of Brunsonâ€™s contact dermatitis is the law of the case, and thus the remand order neither involves the merits nor affects a substantial right. 
CONCLUSION
Since the remand to the single commissioner is limited to those matters included in Employerâ€™s appeal to the Commission, the compensability of Brunsonâ€™s contact dermatitis claim will not be relitigated.Â  Accordingly, the Commissionâ€™s remand order neither involves the merits nor affects a substantial right.Â  The circuit court correctly dismissed the appeal from this interlocutory order.Â  
APPEAL DISMISSED. 
 HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL, J., concur.  

[1] Brunson attempts to raise numerous grounds on appeal beyond the appealability issue.Â  However, the only ruling obtained from the circuit court relates to the appealability of the Commissionâ€™s order.Â  Thus, the remainder of the issues are not properly preserved for appeal.Â  See, e.g., Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 23, 602 S.E.2d 772, 779-780 (2004) (holding that issues and arguments are preserved for appellate review only when they are raised to and ruled on by the lower court).Â  Our dismissal of this appeal as interlocutory, in any event, precludes us from addressing the remaining issues.
